finding: The R702W mutation in NOD2 was encountered in a heterozygous form in the twins, signaling a candidate variant for early onset leprosy. This mutation has been previously recognized as a co-dominant risk factor for Crohn's disease, highlighting its role in immune response and infection.
title: Early onset leprosy reveals a joint effect of LRRK2 and NOD2 variants

finding: The significant association of rs1605379 with impulsivity highlighted its potential impact on behaviors commonly associated with risk.
title: CADM2 is implicated in impulsive personality and numerous other traits by genome- and phenome-wide association studies in humans and mice

finding: The SNP rs6498573 was linked to the MYH11 gene, encoding a smooth muscle myosin heavy chain. This variant exhibited eQTL effects with a posterior probability of 63.2%. Overexpression of MYH11 was observed in enlarged hemorrhoidal tissue, suggesting its role in muscle contraction relevant to hemorrhoidal disease.
title: Genome-wide analysis of 944,133 individuals provides insights into the etiology of hemorrhoidal disease

finding: This SNP was associated with the cis-regulation of MLYCD and was linked to increased expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL1B and TNF) following Mtb infection, suggesting its role in host response mechanisms.
title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis-dependent Monocyte Expression Quantitative Trait Loci and Tuberculosis Pathogenesis

finding: This putative causal missense variant in ABCA3 was associated with reduced FEV1/FVC and previously linked to pediatric interstitial lung disease.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide association study improves resolution of genes, pathways and pleiotropy for lung function and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: Variant rs11074451 at locus 16p12.3 served as a splicing quantitative trait locus (sQTL) for the nearby GP2 gene, suggesting it has a role in the relationship between depression and type 2 diabetes.
title: Multi-trait genetic analysis identifies novel pleiotropic loci for depression and schizophrenia in East Asians

finding: The variant rs35626903 at locus 16q12.2 has been previously linked to psychological issues in European populations, highlighting its relevance in the context of depression.
title: Multi-trait genetic analysis identifies novel pleiotropic loci for depression and schizophrenia in East Asians

finding: The SNP rs12102767 was associated with the development of non-invasive biomarkers for early detection of breast cancer. It showed a connection to improved interpretability in clinical applications of AI models for cancer diagnosis.
title: BioDecoder: A miRNA Bio-interpretable Neural Network Model for Noninvasive Diagnosis of Breast Cancer

finding: The low-frequency missense variant p.Arg433Ser associated with SNP rs60782127 in the ABCC1 gene showed a posterior probability of causality at 0.99. This variant was linked to changes in glutathione metabolism and lower levels of certain plasma metabolites, supporting its role in the pathophysiology of sickle cell disease.
title: Genomic discovery and functional validation of MRP1 as a novel fetal hemoglobin modulator and potential therapeutic target in sickle cell disease

finding: The common intronic variant rs246232 in the ABCC1 gene had a posterior probability of causality of 0.92, suggesting its potential influence on fetal hemoglobin levels and linking it to the broader implications of MRP1 function.
title: Genomic discovery and functional validation of MRP1 as a novel fetal hemoglobin modulator and potential therapeutic target in sickle cell disease

finding: The FTO rs9939609 polymorphism was found to be associated with elevated homocysteine levels in patients with multiple sclerosis. This finding indicated a potential metabolic link between obesity-related genetic factors and vascular risk in pwMS, highlighting a broader impact on disease pathology.
title: White matter lesion volumes on 3-T MRI in people with MS who had followed a diet- and lifestyle program for more than 10 years

finding: In the context of prostate cancer, the index SNP rs804172 was associated with regulatory effects as demonstrated by a median DeepSEA functionality score of 0.18. This SNP had a maximum mean log e-value (MLE) greater than 2, indicating a higher likelihood of regulatory effects compared to a reference distribution. Furthermore, it contributed to the discovery of novel genomic regions, supporting its relevance in cancer pathways.
title: Novel discoveries and enhanced genomic prediction from modelling genetic risk of cancer age-at-onset

finding: The SNP rs17794645 was associated with decreased body weight in mice, demonstrating the genetic effects on weight regulation and adiposity.
title: The genetic architecture of changes in adiposity during adulthood

finding: The SNP rs8047587 at the FTO locus was identified as a novel GWAS signal for PCOS, reinforcing earlier findings from a candidate gene study. This association underscored the relationship between increased BMI and higher risk of PCOS, indicating that genetic predisposition to obesity might play a role in the condition.
title: Genomic and proteomic evidence for hormonal and metabolic foundations of polycystic ovary syndrome

finding: The SNP rs7206309 was determined to be significant in association with PSA levels, informing the ongoing research regarding prostate cancer biomarkers.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The SNP rs7193778, located near the genes NFAT5 and TERF2, was previously associated with urate levels. The DeepPheWAS analysis revealed various associations with blood sodium levels, which had not been documented before in the GWAS Catalog.
title: DeepPheWAS: an R package for phenotype generation and association analysis for phenome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs924135, located in the ABCC1 gene, was found to significantly interact with rs17806888, accounting for around 32% of the variance in differentiating between cognitive decline trajectories in Alzheimer’s disease. Its influence on succinylcarnitine levels suggested a genetic basis for altered energy metabolism affecting cognitive outcomes.
title: Individual bioenergetic capacity as a potential source of resilience to Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs4787491 was part of the significant associations for the gene YPEL3. It was observed in a region associated with BMI, linking it to the transcriptional pathways influencing body mass index.
title: Integrating Genetic and Transcriptomic Data to Identify Genes Underlying Obesity Risk Loci

finding: Rs9925964 was also identified as a significant variant for ZNF646. This SNP was included in the same region as YPEL3 and was connected through a SNP-transcript-BMI association relevant to body mass index.
title: Integrating Genetic and Transcriptomic Data to Identify Genes Underlying Obesity Risk Loci

finding: This SNP was reported as a significant variant associated with SPNS1 and was part of the BMI locus analysis, contributing to the ongoing understanding of genetic factors affecting BMI.
title: Integrating Genetic and Transcriptomic Data to Identify Genes Underlying Obesity Risk Loci

finding: The rs28545123 variant at the PDXDC1 locus showed a protective association with DNMT3A-CH (OR = 0.90 [0.87-0.93], P = 2.15 x 10^-8), contributing further to the identification of loci influencing CH risk.
title: Comparative analysis of 136,401 Admixed Americans and 419,228 Europeans reveals ancestry-specific genetic determinants of clonal haematopoiesis

finding: At rs5923, the BP allele was associated with both increased and decreased expression of PSMB10 in various blood immune cells, demonstrating a complex regulatory role in gene expression with significant p-values reported.
title: Pathway-based polygenic score analysis identifies the NRF2-KEAP1 and mRNA splicing - minor pathways as enriched in shared genetic variation between chronotype and bipolar disorder

finding: Associated with FTO, this SNP was recognized for its role in determining risk factors for substance use.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: This SNP was linked to FTO with significant evidence (p=6.50e-32) suggesting a role in addiction risk across ancestries.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: The SNP rs542745170, mapping to WWOX, exhibited significant interaction with STST for PP in Hispanic populations, confirmed by a P-value of 3.1×10^-5, emphasizing its involvement in blood pressure.
title: A Large-Scale Genome-Wide Study of Gene-Sleep Duration Interactions for Blood Pressure in 811,405 Individuals from Diverse Populations

finding: The SNP rs6497523 was associated with ASD through its overlap with an open chromatin region necessary for telencephalon development, further tying it to the developmental mechanisms involved in ASD.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The variant rs72824905 in the PLCG2 gene was previously found to be protective against Alzheimer's disease (AD), frontotemporal dementia, and dementia with Lewy bodies, while being associated with an increased likelihood of longevity.
title: The effect of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants on longevity

finding: This SNP was another lead variant for hypothyroidism with elevated effect allele frequency in EstBB and FinnGen cohorts, denoting its relevance in these populations.
title: Uncovering the Shared Genetic Components of Thyroid Disorders and Reproductive Health

finding: The SNP in CACNA1H (rs4984636) was exclusively associated with late T2D diagnosis, contributing to findings that differentiated genetic risk based on age of T2D onset.
title: Sex-specific genetic loci linked to early and late onset type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs11860769 was identified as a pleiotropic index SNP during the analyses, showing an opposite effect on the risk of restless legs syndrome (RLS) and Parkinson's disease (PD). This finding suggested that rs11860769 may violate the assumptions of Mendelian randomization in the context of the analyses performed to assess the causal relationship between RLS and PD.
title: Lack of Causal Effects or Genetic Correlation between Restless Legs Syndrome and Parkinson’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs7189975 in the LUC7L gene was positively associated with mean corpuscular haemoglobin. The trans-ancestry beta was 0.105 with a p-value of 2.82×10^-102, and there was significant heterogeneity (p=6.03×10^-104). In the European ancestry, the effect size was positive (beta=0.134, p=2.26×10^-151) whereas it was negative in the African ancestry (beta=-0.336, p=1.81×10^-58).
title: Inter-population differences of allele frequency and regulome tagging are associated with the heterogeneity of loci identified by cross-ancestry genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs217181, linked to TXNL4B, displayed significant associations with LDL cholesterol across ancestries, highlighting the genetic diversity in lipid metabolism regulation.
title: Inter-population differences of allele frequency and regulome tagging are associated with the heterogeneity of loci identified by cross-ancestry genome-wide association studies

finding: Identified as a trans-meQTL in ZNF75A, this missense variant (p.Val325Ala) was associated with the expression of 45 genes, which included significant associations with methylation levels at cg17944885 and other related CpGs associated with late DKD progression.
title: Blood methylation biomarkers are associated with diabetic kidney disease progression in type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs11642015 was identified as the lead SNP within the FTO locus for HFpEF, showing a significant association (OR 1.10; p-value 6.30×10^-3), indicating it is a risk factor for HFpEF.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: The SNP rs12933292 located in NFAT5 replicated significant associations with HF in recent studies, highlighting its potential impact in heart failure genetics.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: The SNP rs2106261 in the ZFHX3 gene was related to maintenance of low inflammation levels, which contributed to a reduction in atrial fibrillation recurrence after pulmonary vein isolation. This finding indicated a genetic influence involving ZFHX3 in arrhythmias, particularly in contexts relevant to familial atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).
title: Integrative analyses identify potential key genes and calcium-signaling pathway in familial AVNRT using whole-exome sequencing

finding: The well-known FTO variant rs7202116 was found to be associated with the phenotypic variability of body mass index (BMI) at a significance level of P=2.4E-10, based on a sample of 131,233 individuals. This association was established through a two-stage regression approach, wherein BMI was initially regressed on the SNP genotype followed by regressing the squared residuals on the SNP genotype again to test for the SNP's association with the variance in BMI.
title: On Mendelian Randomization Mixed-Scale Treatment Effect Robust Identification (MR MiSTERI) and Estimation for Causal Inference

finding: This SNP (FTO) was associated with non-caffeine substances, linking it to energy metabolism and bodyweight management.
title: Habitual Coffee Consumption Increases Risks for Metabolic Diseases: Genome-wide Association Studies and a Phenotype-wide Two Sample Mendelian Randomization Analysis

finding: The rs10852372 variant was found near C16orf72, which is a regulator of telomere integrity. Its association with sporadic miscarriage highlighted the role of telomere length regulation in reproductive outcomes.
title: Trans-ancestral Genome Wide Association Study of Sporadic and Recurrent Miscarriage

finding: The SNP rs217184 was noted as the leading SNP in the second most significant locus associated with MetaboAgeMort. It was located within the genes TXNL4B, HPR, and HP on chromosome 16, further reinforcing the importance of this genetic factor in the context of metabolomic aging and its potential implications for targeted therapies.
title: Heterogeneous metabolomic aging across the same age and prediction of health outcome

finding: The rs1558902 variant within the FTO gene was associated with fat mass and eating behavior. In the context of the study, this SNP was used in conjunction with polygenic indices related to BMI and fat mass percentage. The findings indicated that even when controlling for various factors such as socioeconomic position and maternal BMI, the PGI including this SNP showed a strong association with BMI in younger cohorts, suggesting that the effects of this genetic variant on BMI were significant and that its influence may have increased in more recent generations.
title: Genetic Risk for High Body Mass Index Before and Amidst the Obesity Epidemic: Cross-Cohort Analysis of Four British Birth Cohort Studies

finding: SNP rs9939609, located in the FTO gene, was associated with atypical subtypes of major depressive disorder. Its association was noted in the context of a previous study that examined the effects of this SNP across different MDD subtypes, further corroborating its relevance in the genetic landscape of depressive symptoms.
title: Genetic structure of major depression symptoms across clinical and community cohorts

finding: The rs1805008 variant in the MC1R gene was positively associated with melanoma, showing an odds ratio of 1.56 when comparing individuals with at least one melanoma and another cancer to cancer-free controls.
title: Assessment of Genetic Susceptibility to Multiple Primary Cancers through Whole-Exome Sequencing in Two Large Multi-Ancestry Studies

finding: The rs9934438 SNP was identified as a lead NAFLD-S SNP. Its A allele was associated with a protective effect against NAFLD, indicated by lower VKORC1 expression in the liver. This association extended to various cardiometabolic traits, including reduced hip and waist circumference, lower body mass index (BMI), and favorable lipid profiles such as lower plasma triglycerides and ApoB levels. Furthermore, knockdown studies suggested that lower VKORC1 levels might be protective against NAFLD development.
title: A functional genomic framework to elucidate novel causal non-alcoholic fatty liver disease genes

finding: The SNP rs2884737 was associated within the VKORC1 locus and showed significant colocalization signals with various cardiometabolic traits, including BMI and triglyceride levels. This splice donor variant was linked to a dysregulation of lipid metabolism genes in hepatocytes when VKORC1 was knocked down, indicating its role in influencing metabolic pathways related to NAFLD.
title: A functional genomic framework to elucidate novel causal non-alcoholic fatty liver disease genes

finding: The SNP rs12446759 was associated with the PLCG2 Alzheimer’s disease risk locus. It acted through increased expression of the lncRNA RP11-960L18.1 and fusion isoforms containing regions from both RP11-960L18.1 and PLCG2. The variation was observed to alter splice site choice, significantly impacting isoform usage and expression. Its minor allele was linked to modifications in transcript usage QTLs.
title: Long-read RNA-seq atlas of novel microglia isoforms elucidates disease-associated genetic regulation of splicing

finding: SNP rs12446781, along with rs12446759, demonstrated a colocalization effect impacting splice site choice in the region upstream of PLCG2. It was identified as being closely linked to a splice site change affecting the upstream fusion isoform, enhancing the expression of the neighboring lncRNA.
title: Long-read RNA-seq atlas of novel microglia isoforms elucidates disease-associated genetic regulation of splicing

finding: This SNP weakened enhancer activity and disrupted transcription factor binding sites in ITGAM, highlighting its dual role in affecting immune regulation and SLE risk.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS analysis pipeline defines functional variants and target genes for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

finding: Associated with smoking initiation, this deleterious coding SNP in FBRS was identified as significant for tobacco use disorder.
title: Multi-ancestry meta-analysis of tobacco use disorders based on electronic health record data prioritizes novel candidate risk genes and reveals associations with numerous health outcomes

finding: The SNP rs55650311 in ECI1 was associated with dodecadienoate levels, linking it to fatty acid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The rs7194734 SNP, associated with the MPHOSPH6 gene, was also linked to a higher risk of coronary heart disease. This SNP's findings were consistent with the study's conclusions regarding the causal role of shorter TL in influencing cardiac health.
title: Leukocyte Telomere Length and Cardiac Structure and Function: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The variant rs78887288, located in the ATP2C2 gene, was identified as a rare non-synonymous variant (Chr16:84405221 GRCh38.p12, NM_001286527:exon3:c.G304A:p.V102M) implicated in specific language impairment (SLI). It exhibited a higher frequency in language impairment cases (1.8%, N=360) compared to dyslexia (0.8%, N=520) and ADHD (0.7%, N=150), aligning with previous association findings. The same variant was previously reported in an exome sequencing study as associated with language impairment, reinforcing its potential role in language-related phenotypes. Carriers of this variant showed lower performance on reading and language metrics, highlighting its functional relevance.
title: A rare missense variant in the ATP2C2 gene is associated with language impairment and related measures

finding: The SNP rs4986970 near LCAT was identified as key in the modulation of HDL levels and was part of a cluster that included other HDL-related genes, confirming its role in coronary heart disease through its involvement in cholesterol esterification processes.
title: Lipo-proteomic and metabolic fine-mapping of genetic lipid risk loci

finding: The SNP rs821840 near CETP was found to cluster with LCAT in relation to HDL characteristics, indicating its significant impact on HDL physiology and contribution to cardiovascular risk associated with lipid profiles.
title: Lipo-proteomic and metabolic fine-mapping of genetic lipid risk loci

finding: The SNP rs752371476 was identified as a heterozygous mutation c.1206G>A (p.Trp402*) in the CCDC78 gene, leading to a premature stop codon at position 402 of the protein. This finding was significant as it contributed to the understanding of CCDC78 as a causative gene for autosomal dominant centronuclear myopathy-4 (CNM4). The study provided detailed histopathological features and demonstrated CCDC78's interaction with skeletal muscle proteins, thus supporting its role in the pathogenesis of CNM4.
title: CCDC78: unveiling the function of a novel gene associated to hereditary myopathy

finding: The rs11117420 SNP related to the IRF8 locus exhibited significant interactions between SNPs overlapping enhancer regions and the IRF8 promoter specifically in CD14+ monocytes, which correlated with a much higher expression of IRF8 in these cells (log2FC = -4.47, FDR = 3.11 × 10^-72).
title: Functional genomics in primary T cells and monocytes identifies mechanisms by which genetic susceptibility loci influence systemic sclerosis risk

finding: The SNP rs7185636 was associated with a 22 kb deletion at the IQCK locus, which exhibited nominal associations with depression in the ROS/MAP cohort. The findings suggested a similar pattern of association to those seen with AD GWAS SNPs, highlighting the potential link between this genetic variant and both depression and AD/ADRD traits.
title: Structural variants linked to Alzheimer’s Disease and other common age-related clinical and neuropathologic traits

finding: For rs2937127, the findings indicated that it served as an intronic tag eSNP which demonstrated no eQTL effect in females. However, in males, the minor allele was associated with downregulation of the TERF2 gene expression, showing a significant association (FDR = 0.04). This SNP was situated within the WWP2 gene, which itself showed male-biased expression regulation in the study, highlighting its relevance in male-specific transcriptional responses to cortisol.
title: Autosomal sex-biased genetic regulation of the stress response

finding: In the general population analysis, the removal of the outlier SNP rs72786786 resulted in a weakly significant P-value of 0.047 using the MR-IVW method and MR-LASSO estimation. This indicated that this SNP might influence the causal association between insulin resistance (IR) and major depressive disorder (MDD) within the population studied. Additionally, the overall analysis did not support a significant causal association between IR and MDD, suggesting that while this SNP was notable in the population-level analysis, its effect was not strong enough across the broader dataset.
title: Sex-Specific causal dynamic between Insulin resistance and MDD, a bidirectional Mendelian randomization study

finding: It was also included in the 47 lead variants that were significantly associated with HF, contributing to concordant effects that validated its role in HF risk.
title: Common- and rare-variant genetic architecture of heart failure across the allele frequency spectrum

finding: This variant, nearest to SUCLA2, was significant in predicting time to irreversible EDSS outcomes, similar to rs111399831, with significant hazard ratios reported.
title: Not all roads lead to the immune system: The Genetic Basis of Multiple Sclerosis Severity Implicates Central Nervous System and Mitochondrial Involvement

finding: The variant rs12598836 was identified as a MA-specific risk variant at the <italic>HMOX2</italic> locus with a probability above 95% indicating its association solely with migraine with aura.
title: Genome-wide analysis of 102,084 migraine cases identifies 123 risk loci and subtype-specific risk alleles

finding: This intronic variant in the FTO gene had a strong association with ASAT (P = 1.3 x 10^-22), GFAT (P = 1.2 x 10^-12), and VAT (P = 3.3 x 10^-10), indicating its relevance to overall body fat distribution and obesity.
title: Inherited basis of visceral, abdominal subcutaneous and gluteofemoral fat depots

finding: Located in the 16q12.1 region, the SNP rs1544637 was associated with mean diffusivity (AD) across the whole brain, indicating overlaps with insomnia traits.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The genetic overlap of rs4784256 in 16q12.2 emphasized its role as it relates to brain structures and sleep indices.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The rs1421085 variant was similarly noted among the five maternally derived variants linked to preeclampsia (PE) and was associated with an increased risk for hypertension (HTN), highlighting genetic overlap in pathophysiologies.
title: Spatially Constrained Gene Regulation Identifies Key Genetic Contributions of Preeclampsia, Hypertension and Proteinuria

finding: The SNP rs9939609 located in the FTO gene was analyzed as part of a two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) study to estimate its causal effect on Body Mass Index (BMI) and systolic blood pressure (SBP). This analysis utilized data from the 1958 National Survey of Health and Development British cohort at 11 different time points between ages 2 and 53. The study also ensured associations were validated through further research including a study of Danish individuals that reported FTO-hypertension associations and additional support from the Rotterdam Study, confirming consistency across different cohorts. Findings indicated that MR estimates should be viewed as effects of changing the underlying liability for BMI rather than direct causal effects at a specific time point, highlighting the need for awareness of how genetic variants influence exposures over time.
title: Interpretation of mendelian randomization using one measure of an exposure that varies over time

finding: Variant rs9940128 was significantly associated with overweight and obesity, linking it to metabolic health issues that may be relevant to AD. This association was consistent across both UKBB and eMERGE.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: This SNP associated with the FTO gene showed a GWS signal in the OUD-MTAG analysis, highlighting its involvement in the genetic factors contributing to OUD.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: The SNP rs16952251 was the second most significant lead SNP, positioned near the RBL2 gene with a p-value of 2.637 x 10^-11. This locus was further discussed in terms of its association with gene expression in the brain.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis of age at onset of walking

finding: The SNP rs17800727 was identified as a likely candidate for functional impact related to age at onset of walking as it caused a missense variant (p.Tyr210Cys) in the RBL2 gene, annotated as likely damaging based on PolyPhen2 scores. It co-occurred with decreased RBL2 expression, evidencing a 'double hit' effect.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis of age at onset of walking

finding: The SNP rs4638568 was noted for being associated with all epilepsy groups, which provided new insights into potential genetic factors across various forms of epilepsy. It was linked to HEATR3, a transporter channel associated gene.
title: Systematic review of genome wide association studies (GWAS) of epilepsy identifies common risk variants and associated genes

finding: The SNP rs9939609 was associated with traits of broad clinical relevance, such as its connection to obesity-related phenotypes. This finding was significant in the context of the PAGEANT framework, which considered qualitative assessments of genetic characteristics for various traits. The SNP's genotype had implications for determining risk susceptibility in individuals.
title: PAGEANT: Personal Access to Genome and Analysis of Natural Traits

finding: The SNP rs72802342 was identified as a candidate causal variant at the CTRB1/2 locus, with a T1D posterior probability of 0.26. This variant colocalized with plasma protein QTLs for multiple pancreatic enzymes and overlapped with cis-regulatory elements in acinar cells, supporting the hypothesis that altered acinar regulation contributes to the association between T1D risk and pancreatic enzyme levels.
title: Circulating pancreatic enzyme levels are a causal biomarker of type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs3924376 was identified as a cis eQTL in CD4NC cells for the gene SPNS1, which is involved in mitochondrial homeostasis. Additionally, this SNP acted as a trans eQTL for the gene MRPL32 located on chromosome 7, encoding Mitochondrial ribosomal protein L32. This result was part of the genome-wide scan of genetic effects on single-cell expression conducted by SAIGE-QTL.
title: Efficient and accurate mixed model association tool for single-cell eQTL analysis

finding: The SNP rs729876 was classified among those with very strong evidence for an association with periodontal disease. It contributed to the significant findings in the analysis, notably in relation to colorectal cancer.
title: Two-sample Mendelian randomization analysis of associations between periodontal disease and risk of colorectal, lung, and pancreatic cancers

finding: The rs3087456 polymorphism, located on the promoter III of the CIITA gene, was associated with increased 28-day mortality in patients with septic shock. Specifically, patients with the GG genotype exhibited a 2.29 fold increased risk of death compared to those with AA or AG genotypes. Additionally, circulating monocyte HLA-DR expression was significantly lower among patients with the GG genotype, suggesting that this polymorphism adversely affected the immune response in this cohort.
title: CIITA G-286A promoter polymorphism impairs monocytes HLA-DR expression in septic shock and is rescued by interferon-γ

finding: Found near the CREBBP locus, rs76564172 exhibited significant association with an Odds Ratio of 1.31 (95% CI=1.25-1.38, p=9.64×10^-9), demonstrating its significance in studies of genetic risk factors for COVID-19.
title: Novel risk loci for COVID-19 hospitalization among admixed American populations

finding: The variant rs1421085 at the FTO locus was identified as a putative causal variant for body mass index (BMI), body fat percentage (BFP), hip circumference (HC), and waist circumference (WC). It was supported by previous functional studies for its role in adipocyte thermogenesis regulation. The analysis indicated that rs1421085 was significantly associated with BMI, showcasing the importance of functional annotations.
title: Genome-wide fine-mapping improves identification of causal variants

finding: The variant rs76488452 was uncovered as a secondary signal at the FTO locus, noted for its evolutionary conservation in primates and its significant association in COJO analysis. Although only nominally significant in the GWAS marginal analysis, it was included in a local credible set and provided evidence of a masked effect.
title: Genome-wide fine-mapping improves identification of causal variants

finding: Found in the significant super variant chr16_57 associated with COVID-19, with an OR of 1.394 (p=1.19×10^-7), highlighting its relevance in the studied context.
title: Deep learning identified genetic variants associated with COVID-19 related mortality

finding: The SNP rs112525682 on chromosome 16 showed suggestive association with a beta of 1.42 and a p-value of 2.64×10^-7. It was located in the gene GSE1, but due to lack of a direct test in other cohorts, this result could not be verified further.
title: Phenotypic and genetic factors are associated with absence of cardiomyopathy symptoms in PLN c.40_42delAGA carriers

finding: The SNP rs35994878, located in TCF25, was associated with an 11% increase in posterior brain arterial diameter (P=2.94×10^-8), indicating its critical role in influencing vascular dimensions.
title: Chromosome 10q24.32 Variants Associate with Brain Arterial Diameters in Diverse Populations: A Genome-Wide Association Study

finding: The SNP rs1421085 was identified as an important genetic variant associated with obesity through its role in the FTO gene. This SNP was shown to underlie the association between the FTO locus and obesity by activating the IRX3 and IRX5 genes, which are involved in the differentiation of adipocyte subtypes. The context of this finding relates to genetic predisposition to increased body mass index (BMI), emphasizing how genetic factors can influence dietary preferences and appetite regulation.
title: The Impact of Late-Career Job Loss and Genotype on Body Mass Index

finding: This variant in CNOT1 was identified as strongly linked with lead SNPs and was found to be population-enriched, indicating its potential functional significance in mood disorders.
title: Genome-wide significant risk loci for mood disorders in the Old Order Amish founder population

finding: This variant in CNOT1 was found in perfect linkage disequilibrium with rs201250006 and considered potentially deleterious due to its strong linkage with lead SNPs.
title: Genome-wide significant risk loci for mood disorders in the Old Order Amish founder population

finding: The variant rs7187776 in the 5' UTR of the TUFM gene was found to be positively associated with increased chromatin accessibility specifically in microglial cells. The alternate allele was associated with increased body mass index (BMI), and a decreased caudate volume. This suggests that the genetic variation may exert its effects through enhanced chromatin accessibility and subsequently affect gene regulation, thereby influencing brain morphology and BMI.
title: Exploring the molecular basis of the genetic correlation between body mass index and brain morphological traits

finding: Found within the C-type Lectin Domain Containing 16A (CLEC16A) gene, rs8062322 was strongly linked to pSSNS with a p-value of 1.61 x 10^-10. Similar to rs55730955, it showed no overlap with open chromatin regions, pointing to a potential mechanistic pathway that does not rely on chromatin accessibility.
title: Multi-population genome-wide association study implicates both immune and non-immune factors in the etiology of pediatric steroid sensitive nephrotic syndrome

finding: The SNP rs28372783 was associated with a cis-pQTL for the protein CDH1 in the Chinese Biobank (CKB) study, which was not observed in the UK Biobank Protein Precursor (UKB-PPP) datasets. This indicates that this protein's regulation may have unique determinants in the East Asian population.
title: Ancestry diversity in the genetic determinants of the human plasma proteome and associated new drug targets

finding: The c.13801delG variant (rs752405406) was found to be enriched in the Finnish population, with an allele frequency of 0.0005309. This variant is predicted to contribute significantly to the incidence of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) in Finnish patients as evidenced in this study.
title: HYDIN variants cause primary ciliary dyskinesia in the Finnish population

finding: The c.12899G>C variant (rs200169224) was observed to be more common in the Finnish population with an allele frequency of 0.003242. It was also noted that this variant can be found in broader global populations, including European, African, and American, indicating its potential role as a recurrent cause of PCD particularly within the Finnish cohort.
title: HYDIN variants cause primary ciliary dyskinesia in the Finnish population

finding: The variant rs173539 was linked to increased levels of the APOA1 protein, which corresponded to elevated high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels, thus indicating its role in regulating this trait.
title: Plasma Proteome Variation and its Genetic Determinants in Children and Adolescents

finding: SNP rs876987 was uniquely associated with an inverse effect on PW relative to BW, located in the SLC7A5 gene. It was a significant eQTL in placenta, influencing essential amino acid uptake vital for placental function.
title: Genome-wide association study of placental weight in 179,025 children and parents reveals distinct and shared genetic influences between placental and fetal growth

finding: A significant association at rs2161648 (p=4.8e-08, MAF=0.41318, OR=1.268) occurred near BCAR1 and CFDP1 in spontaneous pneumothorax, indicating potential links to lung function.
title: Large-scale trans-ethnic replication and discovery of genetic associations for rare diseases with self-reported medical data

finding: As with rs4646249 and rs894211, the SNP rs12691049 was implicated in significant associations with lipid species within the context of CAD risk variants.
The SNP rs9931494 near FTO was associated with AF as well as multiple cardiometabolic traits, indicating a shared genetic background in the etiology of AF and cardio-metabolic risk.
title: Deciphering the genetic architecture of atrial fibrillation offers insights into disease prediction, pathophysiology and downstream sequelae

finding: The rs9939973 SNP, an intronic variant within the FTO gene, was reported to have a positive association with obesity (increased BMI) but a negative association with alcohol use disorder (AUD), indicating that the effect allele was linked to reduced likelihood of AUD. This finding highlighted the discordance in effect directions between AUD and BMI, contributing to the lack of genetic correlation.
title: Alcohol use disorder and body mass index show genetic pleiotropy and shared neural associations

finding: The SNP rs13331259, an intronic variant in the FAM234A gene, was associated with a significant effect on haemoglobin concentration in the African population (MAF = 0.11). It had a P-value of 3.32 × 10^-4 and an estimated IRNT effect size of -0.2495, indicating a decrease of approximately -3.10 g/L in haemoglobin concentration per allele.
title: Statistical haemoglobin thresholds to define anaemia across the lifecycle

finding: The SNP rs563555492 was identified as a missense variant in the PIEZO1 gene and exhibited independent significance in the South Asian context. However, it did not show significant associations in the larger non-South Asian studies.
title: Statistical haemoglobin thresholds to define anaemia across the lifecycle

finding: The SNP rs180924818 showed a strong association with the likelihood of developing LiD, with a HR of 3.13 and a p-value of 6.27 x 10^-9. This variant was found in close proximity (0.15 Mb upstream) to the XYLT1 gene on chromosome 16.
title: Genetic meta-analysis of levodopa induced dyskinesia in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The SNP rs8404 was associated with multiple shape features of the left hippocampus and identified as an eQTL for several genes including CDK10.
title: Genetic influences on the shape of brain ventricular and subcortical structures

finding: In the European ancestry GWAS meta-analysis, the rs7203642 variant located within the UMOD gene was associated with increased blood NfL levels, with P = 1.37x10-8. This finding indicated a significant link between the genetic variant and neuro-axonal damage across neurodegenerative disorders.
title: Genome-wide Association Study Meta-analysis of Neurofilament light (NfL) levels in blood reveals novel loci related to neurodegeneration

finding: In the analysis of the 17q24 locus, the rs77924615 variant was associated with increased blood NfL levels (effect = -0.041, P = 3.77x10-8) within the PDILT gene. Similar to other findings, this relationship emphasized the genetic basis for neurodegenerative processes.
title: Genome-wide Association Study Meta-analysis of Neurofilament light (NfL) levels in blood reveals novel loci related to neurodegeneration

finding: The SNP rs8050136 was linked to BMI and had a p-value of 1.6E-08 alongside a beta of 0.064, reflecting a positive association with increased BMI.
title: Improved Type 2 Diabetes Risk Stratification in the Qatar Biobank Cohort by Ensemble Learning Classifier Incorporating Multi-Trait, Population-Specific, Polygenic Risk Scores

finding: This SNP was identified as significantly associated with the mild progression subtype (Subtype I) of PD.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: This SNP was associated with the mild progression subtype (Subtype I) of PD.
title: Comprehensively modeling heterogeneous symptom progression for Parkinson’s disease subtyping

finding: The SNP rs113078989, which mapped to the gene RBFOX1, exhibited significant male-biased effects on regional cortical gray matter volume (GMV) in the supplementary motor region (6MA). Male carriers of the CT genotype showed higher GMV compared to homozygous TT individuals. This SNP was associated with several male-biased neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders, suggesting its role in influencing sex differences in brain anatomy and potentially the prevalence of these disorders.
title: A sex-stratified analysis of the genetic architecture of human brain anatomy

finding: A missense variant rs117169628:G>A (p.Pro256Leu) in SLC22A31 was identified as conferring risk for hospitalization with an odds ratio (OR = 1.09; 95% CI = 1.06, 1.13; P = 2.6 × 10^-8). This gene is involved in solute transport across membranes and is co-regulated with other surfactant proteins.
title: Mapping the human genetic architecture of COVID-19: an update

finding: The SNP rs1121980, located in the adipose-associated gene FTO, had a positive causal effect estimate for both PCOS and pre-eclampsia, highlighting its significance in the genetic basis of these disorders.
title: The role of obesity in female reproductive conditions: A Mendelian Randomisation study

finding: The SNP rs7498665 was linked to insulin resistance in obesity and presented a positive causal effect for both PCOS and pre-eclampsia, showcasing its role in the connection between obesity and reproductive health.
title: The role of obesity in female reproductive conditions: A Mendelian Randomisation study

finding: The SNP rs3915499 demonstrated associations with two distinct pathways, 'renal' and 'vessel', linked to monogenic diseases caused by the disruption of the smooth muscle myosin heavy-chain 11 gene. However, it was suggested that a 'vessel'-only assignment could be more appropriate considering its connection to familial thoracic aortic aneurysm 4, which highlights the structural abnormalities of the aorta.
title: Distinct pathway-based effects of blood pressure and body mass index on cardiovascular traits: comparison of novel Mendelian Randomization approaches

finding: Located within chr16:72333576-72697419 and associated with phoneme awareness, rs2158266 was noted as being suggestively significant and representative of prior findings concerning dyslexia.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association analysis of quantitative reading skill and dyslexia improves gene discovery

finding: The SNP rs12051272, found at the CDH13 locus, qualified as a significant association with adiponectin levels, effectively remaining statistically significant in analyses adjusting for observed heterogeneity.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis, fine-mapping, and gene prioritization approach to characterize the genetic architecture of adiponectin

finding: The SNP rs2925979 was recognized as a significant putative causal variant in the analyses, demonstrating its association with adiponectin.
title: A multi-ancestry genome-wide meta-analysis, fine-mapping, and gene prioritization approach to characterize the genetic architecture of adiponectin

finding: Association of rs4985556 with increased risk for Alzheimer's disease (MAF=12.2%; beta=0.07, p-value<2.3×10−8) was noted, indicating strong structural consequences affecting dimerization and secretion of IL-34.
title: From genome to phenome via the proteome: broad capture, antibody-based proteomics to explore disease mechanisms

finding: The missense variant rs8046424 was associated with reduced childhood obesity (MAF=48.2%; beta=-0.008, p-value<4.4×10−9), highlighting its structural role in modulating risk for this condition.
title: From genome to phenome via the proteome: broad capture, antibody-based proteomics to explore disease mechanisms

finding: The variant rs2042395 exhibited a significantly higher frequency in Europeans (0.77) compared to Africans (0.19), with a Fisher test p-value of 4.94 × 10<sup>−323</sup>. It was previously associated with the Well-being spectrum in individuals of European ancestry.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Pulmonary Function in Europeans and Africans from the UK Biobank Identifies Distinct Variants

finding: The SNP rs3748400 also showed a higher frequency in Europeans (0.78) versus Africans (0.19), with a significant p-value of 6.92 × 10<sup>−323</sup>, although no prior association was noted for this SNP.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Pulmonary Function in Europeans and Africans from the UK Biobank Identifies Distinct Variants

finding: The variant rs8045843 had a frequency of 0.78 in Europeans and 0.17 in Africans (p = 8.89 × 10<sup>−323</sup>), previously linked to sensitivity to environmental stress and adversity in Europeans.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Pulmonary Function in Europeans and Africans from the UK Biobank Identifies Distinct Variants

finding: The variant rs12925700 was reported to be considerably more frequent in Europeans than Africans, associated with pulmonary function and cited in prior studies.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Pulmonary Function in Europeans and Africans from the UK Biobank Identifies Distinct Variants

finding: Located in C16orf95, this SNP showed association with CSF pTau levels, contributing to the understanding of tau pathology in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Genome-wide meta-analysis for Alzheimer’s disease cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers

finding: This SNP was associated with the ZFHX3 gene and had significant associations in both MTAG-CES and previous studies.
title: MULTITRAIT ANALYSIS EXPANDS GENETIC RISK FACTORS IN CARDIOEMBOLIC STROKE

finding: The missense variant rs144651842 at 16p12.1 was linked to the interleukin 4 receptor (IL4R). This association represented a novel relationship with psoriasis, and IL4R had been implicated in prior research related to the disease.
title: Genetic study of psoriasis highlights its close link with socio-economic status and affective symptoms

finding: The SNP rs370477719 in the PLCG2 gene exhibited a rare status (ExAC_SAS score of 0.0004) and was labeled as deleterious by three prediction tools. It showed differential expression in the patient-derived NPCs compared to controls, suggesting its potential role in the cellular migration defects associated with BD.
title: Dysregulation in EGF/ERBB signaling pathway may explain abnormalities in cellular migration in bipolar disorder in patient-derived neural precursors

finding: The SNP rs138637229 in the PLCG2 gene was analyzed separately for the B2 line, characterized as rare (ExAC_SAS score of 0.0001) and identified as deleterious by three of the studied prediction tools. This SNP was linked with altered expression patterns in BD cell lines, further implicating it in the observed migration issues.
title: Dysregulation in EGF/ERBB signaling pathway may explain abnormalities in cellular migration in bipolar disorder in patient-derived neural precursors

finding: The SNP rs11574938 served as a genetic proxy for ITGAL inhibition, with a highly significant association (p = 7.9E-150). This finding was relevant for investigating the off-target effects of statins, particularly concerning immune pathways associated with depression.
title: Statins and antidepressants induce similar in vitro gene expression responses

finding: The SNP chr16:11842460:C:T showed association with the RMI2 gene, which plays a role in telomere lengthening mechanisms via alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT).
title: Genomic, phenomic, and geographic associations of leukocyte telomere length in the United States

finding: The SNP chr16:797597:T:C was associated with AXIN1, a gene that regulates Wnt signaling, known to contribute to telomere maintenance and thus LTL.
title: Genomic, phenomic, and geographic associations of leukocyte telomere length in the United States

finding: The rs8051014 SNP was associated with RP and also previously implicated in coronary artery disease (CAD) among East Asians. It was shown to have a significant association with coronary atherosclerosis in the UK Biobank, indicating a shared genetic architecture between RP and cardiovascular diseases.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies ADRA2A and IRX1 as novel risk genes for Raynaud’s phenomenon

finding: This proxy SNP was identified in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) and was associated with maternal amino acid levels.
title: Causal effects of maternal circulating amino acids on offspring birthweight: a Mendelian randomisation study

finding: The intronic variant rs7499892 identified in the female-only meta-analysis for stroke was associated with a stronger presence in females than in males (in females: effect size (se) = 0.078 (0.014), p-value =1.08×10^-8; in males: effect size (se) = 0.007(0.012), p-value = 0.56), though it did not reach genome-wide significance in the sex-combined meta-analysis.
title: Global Biobank Meta-analysis Initiative: powering genetic discovery across human diseases

finding: The rs9939609 variant was initially used by Labrecque et al. to estimate the lifetime effect of body mass index (BMI) on systolic blood pressure. The study demonstrated that when the relationship between this genetic variant and BMI remained constant over time, the estimates of the effect of BMI on blood pressure were unbiased for different ages (30 and 50 years). However, if the relationship changed over time, estimates could become biased, demonstrating the sensitivity of the findings to the timing of measurement and strength of the genetic-exposure relationship.
title: A systematic literature review of methodological approaches, challenges, and opportunities in the application of Mendelian randomisation to lifecourse epidemiology

finding: The SNP rs1566452 was identified at the 16q22.1 locus and was associated with coronary artery and tibial artery eQTLs. It exhibited significant relationships with various cardiovascular traits, contributing to the understanding of genetic factors involved in cardiovascular diseases.
title: Contribution of leukocyte telomere length to major cardiovascular diseases onset: phenotypic and genetic insights from a large-scale genome-wide cross-trait analysis

finding: The SNP rs7206790 was recognized as a direct causal variant associated with BMI, identified by TGVIS. It remained significant even after applying the Pratt index threshold.
title: Uncovering causal gene-tissue pairs and variants: A multivariable TWAS method controlling for infinitesimal effects

finding: The SNP rs3751813 accompanied rs7206790 as a direct causal variant related to BMI. Its significance persisted after applying the Pratt index threshold, demonstrating its association with obesity.
title: Uncovering causal gene-tissue pairs and variants: A multivariable TWAS method controlling for infinitesimal effects

finding: Associations were found with childhood and adult obesity, suggesting its impact on metabolic conditions related to cardiovascular risks.
title: VAREANT: a bioinformatics application for gene variant reduction and annotation

finding: The SNP rs7140, which corresponds to the missense mutation p.L512M in SPNS1, was identified as a significant contributor to the selection of SPNS1 as a top candidate gene for Parkinson's disease (PD). This gene was associated with the autophagy-lysosomal pathway, critical for PD pathogenesis, particularly in the context of lysosomal sphingolipid metabolism. The expression of SPNS1 was found to be lower in a specific dopaminergic neuron subpopulation vulnerable to degeneration in PD.
title: Identification of novel variants, genes and pathways potentially linked to Parkinson’s disease using machine learning

finding: The study identified that the FTO-rs9939609 polymorphism was associated with metabolic obesity phenotypes and cardiovascular risk, specifically highlighting its link to the variations in the atherogenic index of plasma (AIP). The context established that individuals with certain genotypes of rs9939609 had increased likelihoods of displaying metabolically unhealthy phenotypes, which were significantly correlated with elevated AIP levels.
title: Association between cardiometabolic phenotypes with atherogenic index of plasma: a cross-sectional study from the Azar Cohort Study

finding: The SNP rs450674 was associated with the hub gene MAF in microglia, suggesting its relevance in the context of Alzheimer's Disease.
title: Single-cell RNA sequencing data reveals rewiring of transcriptional relationships in Alzheimer’s Disease associated with risk variants

finding: For rs1140239, the gene ZNF785 was prioritized, suggesting new insights into genetic risk factors for Alzheimer's Disease.
title: Single-cell RNA sequencing data reveals rewiring of transcriptional relationships in Alzheimer’s Disease associated with risk variants

finding: The rs2925049 SNP in the intronic region of the COTL1 gene showed a significant association with estimated bone mineral density (eBMD) in a large cohort of subjects from the UK Biobank. The association yielded a p-value of 2.84×10^-6 and suggested that this SNP was responsible for differences in COTL1 gene expression among genotypes, indicating an important role for COTL1 in determining bone density.
title: Loss of coactosin-like F-actin binding protein 1 (Cotl1) decreases platelet-mediated osteoclastogenesis and causes osteopetrosis phenotypes in mouse

finding: The rs113962704 SNP located on chr.16p13.13 was linked to higher IgA levels (Beta=0.05, P=1.91×10^-12), and was associated with the LITAF gene, a transcription factor relevant to IgA production via monocyte function.
title: Genetic regulation of serum IgA levels and susceptibility to common immune, infectious, kidney, and cardio-metabolic traits

finding: SNP rs10438549 was found to be significant in the analysis of DED, supporting its involvement in genetic predisposition influenced by hot spring residency.
title: Hot Spring Residency and Disease Association: a Crossover Gene-Environment Interaction (GxE) Study in Taiwan

finding: The FTO SNP rs17817288 was included in the Late Rise cluster, showing a strong association with BMI post-adiposity rebound.
title: Characterization of the genetic architecture of BMI in infancy and early childhood reveals age-specific effects and implicates pathways involved in Mendelian obesity

finding: The SNP rs9939609, located at the FTO locus, was analyzed in the context of maternal body mass index (BMI) and its association with offspring adiposity. The study submitted that this SNP had the strongest current evidence for association with BMI. It was considered within various polygenic risk scores to evaluate its impact on maternal BMI and, consequently, on offspring adiposity, indicating possible mechanisms of how maternal genetics could influence the health of the next generation.
title: Exploring the causal effect of maternal pregnancy adiposity on offspring adiposity: Mendelian randomization using polygenic risk scores

finding: The BCKDK rs14235 A allele was associated with milder motor impairment and altered network topology in Parkinson's disease, indicating its role in modifying clinical manifestations and brain network disruption.
title: Striatal dopamine depletion drives disease progression and network topology aberrations specifically by impairing left M1 network

finding: The VKORC1 rs9923231 variant (–1639G>A) was found to be highly prevalent among the participants of the Taiwan Precision Medicine Initiative (TPMI), with nearly all individuals (99.9%) carrying at least one pharmacogenetic variant. This variant was previously associated with altered response to medications, particularly anticoagulants like warfarin, indicating that it plays a significant role in influencing drug metabolism and therapeutic responses in the Han Chinese population.
title: Clinical Impact of Pharmacogenetic Risk Variants in a Large Chinese Cohort

finding: The T allele at rs1558902 within the FTO locus was found to be associated with an increased rate of BMI change from infancy to late childhood (P<7×10⁻⁷), supporting earlier findings of its effect on growth patterns. It was not associated with the adolescent slope (P=0.129), consistent with prior studies.
title: A framework for conducting time-varying genome-wide association studies: An application to body mass index across childhood in six multiethnic cohorts

finding: Variants at rs55872725 showed that the T allele was linked to an increased rate of BMI change from infancy to late childhood (P<7×10⁻⁷), and while it was associated with lower AUC in infancy (P=0.002), its associations varied across childhood and adolescence, replicating findings from Warrington et al. regarding the trajectory of growth.
title: A framework for conducting time-varying genome-wide association studies: An application to body mass index across childhood in six multiethnic cohorts

finding: The SNP rs3927943 was found to be a lead trans-eQTL variant for NPIPB15, explaining a greater than 0.8 proportion of variance in the expression of this gene.
title: Whole Genome DNA and RNA Sequencing of Whole Blood Elucidates the Genetic Architecture of Gene Expression Underlying a Wide Range of Diseases

finding: The common SNP rs6979 at 16q22 was associated with HGSOC risk, although the effect size was relatively small compared to other variants.
title: Large-scale genome-wide association study of 398,238 women unveils seven novel loci associated with high-grade serous epithelial ovarian cancer risk

finding: The missense variant rs7196726 within the ZNF646 gene showed a strong association with dermatophytosis infection (p = 6.60×10−79, beta = 0.07), indicating its potential role in susceptibility to this fungal infection.
title: The genetic basis of dermatophytosis skin infection susceptibility

finding: The variant rs35713203, located in the PRSS53 gene, was also found to be significantly associated with dermatophytosis, with a p-value of 1.90×10−78 and a beta of 0.065, suggesting a contribution to susceptibility.
title: The genetic basis of dermatophytosis skin infection susceptibility

finding: The missense variant rs9938550 in the HSD3B7 gene demonstrated a significant association with dermatophytosis infection (p = 3.43×10−57, beta = 0.056), further implicating genetic factors in susceptibility.
title: The genetic basis of dermatophytosis skin infection susceptibility

finding: The lead variant rs1421085 at the FTO locus evidenced an association with dermatophytosis, which aligns with its previous implication in higher body mass index (BMI), suggesting a connection between obesity and susceptibility to skin infections.
title: The genetic basis of dermatophytosis skin infection susceptibility

finding: The study indicated that the SNP rs12051093 was associated with cervical cancer risk, particularly in the context of Mycoplasma co-infection. This finding highlighted the potential interplay between genetic factors and infectious agents in enhancing the risk of cervical cancer.
title: Oncogenic human papillomavirus and anal microbiota in men who have sex with men and are living with HIV in Northern Taiwan

finding: The variant rs62040020 was identified as having opposite directions of effect on IPF risk in females and males. Specifically, the minor allele (C) was associated with increased risk in females (OR 1.34) and decreased risk in males (OR 0.82). This SNP had not been identified in prior studies of IPF susceptibility.
title: Genome-wide SNP-sex interaction analysis of susceptibility to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

finding: The SNP rs7499892 was initially associated with LDL-C levels in European populations. However, in the study concerning British Pakistanis and Bangladeshis from the Genes & Health cohort, this SNP was found to be strongly associated with HDL-C levels (p=7.08×10^-56) but not with LDL-C levels (p=0.23). This indicated that the transferability of the CETP locus associated with this SNP was variable, as it showed strong significance for HDL-C in the G&H cohort while the predicted relationship with LDL-C did not hold.
title: Transferability of genetic loci and polygenic scores for cardiometabolic traits in British Pakistanis and Bangladeshis

finding: The missense variant rs7185774 in the PKD1L2 gene was associated with 61 risk estimates including psychotic and chronic liver diseases, showing a beta of -0.08 with a p-value of 2.3×10^-43 for psychotic diseases.
title: A predictive atlas of disease onset from retinal fundus photographs

finding: SNP rs12927162 was associated with several sleep-related proxy measures, connecting it to genetic factors influencing physical activity during nocturnal hours.
title: Genome-wide association studies of 27 accelerometry-derived physical activity measurements identifies novel loci and genetic mechanisms

finding: The rs1362756 variant was linked to an additive effect observed in patients, emphasizing its relevance alongside the rs33912345 variant in modulating the risk factors for glaucoma.
title: Genome-wide association meta-analysis identifies novel ancestry-specific primary open-angle glaucoma loci and shared biology with vascular mechanisms and cell proliferation

finding: The findings showed that rs113693994 was a cis-sd-pQTL for cadherin -15 (CDH15), which had significant opposite effect directions in males and females but was identified as a significant pQTL in both sexes. This pointed to its role in cell adhesion and tissue integrity.
title: Similar and different: systematic investigation of proteogenomic variation between sexes and its relevance for human diseases

finding: The SNP rs7188841 was reported to show significantly down-regulated expression of the Glutamate Ionotropic Receptor NMDA Type Subunit 2A (GRIN2A) exon, specifically ENSE00001327113 during exploratory analyses. This finding indicated a potential link to alterations in glutamate systems, which have been widely implicated in schizophrenia.
title: Variant-risk-exon interplay impacts circadian rhythm and dopamine signaling pathway in severe psychiatric disorders

finding: In the African-American cohort, rs12444486 was associated with protection against COVID-19 mortality, unlike in European ancestry subjects.
title: Interferon pathway lupus risk alleles modulate risk of death from acute COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs9924686 was found in the 3’ untranslated region of the serine/threonine-protein kinase gene TAOK2 on chromosome 16. It had a significant p value of 3.3e-15 and was previously implicated by schizophrenia genome-wide association studies (GWAS). The CADD score was 18.16, indicating potential deleterious effects, and it served as an eQTL for several genes linked to metabolic and immunological traits.
title: Cross-ancestry genetic investigation of schizophrenia, cannabis use disorder, and tobacco smoking

finding: The rs372755452 variant was associated with reduced MCH and MCV primarily in East Asian participants and was a significant finding replicated in the study.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: This variant was found to be associated with MCH and MCV, particularly while replicating findings in Hispanic populations, marking it as a significant trait locus in relation to red blood cell characteristics.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: At the HP-TXNL4B locus, rs5471 was associated with antithrombin regulation, where higher expression of HP in liver and blood correlated with higher antithrombin levels.
title: Antithrombin, protein C and protein S: Genome and transcriptome wide association studies identify 7 novel loci regulating plasma levels

finding: The SNP rs5472 was identified as a prognostic biomarker for peptide vaccine efficacy in patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer. This finding was relevant in the context of examining how genetic variations influence treatment outcomes and disease progression in a specific subpopulation of prostate cancer patients.
title: Accurate prognosis for localized prostate cancer through coherent voting networks with multi-omic and clinical data

finding: The SNP rs77924615 was found to have significant colocalization with chronic kidney disease in relation to the S1 subtype of preclinical-T2DM. This finding reinforced the connection between genetic factors of T2DM and chronic kidney disease.
title: Identification of distinct trajectories in preclinical type 2 diabetes and their associations with outcomes

finding: The SNP rs3104783 at the TOX3 locus (16q12.1) showed a significant association with RLS, with a p-value of 1.29 × 10^-12 and an OR of 1.07 (95% CI: 1.05-1.09). This locus was also highlighted for its association with an increased risk of Parkinson's disease, but the effect directions for RLS and Parkinson's disease were contrary.
title: Genomic analysis identifies risk factors in restless legs syndrome

finding: This proxy SNP for rs32470694 was related to higher pancreas fat levels and thus implicated in increasing the risk of PDAC.
title: Genetic Evidence Causally Linking Pancreas Fat to Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs12444726 demonstrated a significant association with pancreas fat levels, which was a determining factor for higher PDAC risk.
title: Genetic Evidence Causally Linking Pancreas Fat to Pancreatic Cancer: A Mendelian Randomization Study

finding: The SNP rs11647753 was identified as novel in the context of shared genetic risk between body mass index (BMI) and multiple sclerosis (MS) through cross-trait meta-analyses, which uncovered a total of 18 novel SNPs. This indicated its significant role in the genetic architecture underlying the comorbidity of these traits.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: Similar to rs11647753, rs11649612 emerged as a positive and original finding. It contributed to the understanding of shared genetic risk in obesity and MS, highlighting the complexity of genetic interactions underlying these phenotypes.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: This SNP was one of the 18 unique shared risk SNPs found through meta-analyses aimed at uncovering genetic correlations between BMI and MS.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: The finding of rs12716974 as a shared risk SNP reinforced the evidence of genetic overlap between BMI and MS as demonstrated in the study.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: Identified as a novel shared risk SNP, rs2289292 contributed to characterizing the genetic commonalities between obesity and MS.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: This SNP was identified as a novel shared risk SNP, revealing further complexities in the genetic interplay between BMI and MS.
title: Investigating shared genetic architecture between obesity and multiple sclerosis

finding: The SNP rs7200543-A in the PDXDC1 gene was associated with a higher risk of fatty liver disease, with an odds ratio of 2.261 (1.1-4.8; p=0.031). Carriers of this SNP showed poor skeletal health, indicating its severity in disease phenotype.
title: Severe liver damage, low bone mineral content, and PDXDC1/TTC39B gene variations linked to NAFLD with metabolic syndrome

finding: The SNP rs12447542 was associated with schizophrenia (SCZ) and linked to the RBFOX1 gene, which encodes a neuron-specific RNA-binding protein and splicing factor. The study found that RBFOX1 was uniquely upregulated in vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) cells across all three disorders: SCZ (logFC = 0.41), bipolar disorder (BD) (logFC = 0.53), and major depressive disorder (MDD) (logFC = 0.22). This indicated a significant role of VIP cells in mediating RBFOX1 effects on various psychiatric disorders.
title: Transcriptomic pathology of neocortical microcircuit cell types across psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs7193263 was associated with major depressive disorder (MDD) and predicted to influence the RBFOX1 gene, which showed upregulation in VIP cells during the study. The finding illustrated that changes in RBFOX1 expression were significant across psychiatric disorders, further emphasizing its role in mood regulation.
title: Transcriptomic pathology of neocortical microcircuit cell types across psychiatric disorders

finding: The SNP rs11077206 was also associated with major depressive disorder (MDD) and predicted to impact the RBFOX1 gene. It was found that RBFOX1 expression showed upregulation in VIP neurons, underpinning its potential involvement in the etiology of MDD and other psychiatric conditions.
title: Transcriptomic pathology of neocortical microcircuit cell types across psychiatric disorders

finding: At 16q12.2 in FTO, the SNP rs17817449 was found to associate significantly with breast texture variation (P = 1.12 × 10−6) and has established links to mammographic density and breast cancer susceptibility.
title: A genome-wide association study of mammographic texture variation

finding: The SNP rs9926151 demonstrated a significant association with a P-value of 3.61×10^-8 in stage 3, contributing to the genetic architecture of LOAD.

The SNP rs153793 was found to have significant implications for age at menarche, as it colocalized with a CNVR associated with reproductive traits, showcasing the potential of using SNPs in understanding reproductive timing.
title: The individual and global impact of copy number variants on complex human traits

finding: Identified as significant for FOXF1 gene, which is crucial in cell adhesion and has significant implications for developmental conditions. This variant was classified as deleterious.
title: The genetics of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH): Integration of population studies and clinical data

finding: The missense variant rs201871085 within KAT8 was significantly associated with AD at a MAF of 0.0108, highlighting its relevance in neurodegeneration linked to AD.
title: Key variants via Alzheimer’s Disease Sequencing Project whole genome sequence data

finding: The analysis of SNP rs258322 identified significant associations with Melanomas of skin, Other non-epithelial cancer of skin, and Actinic Keratosis in the PheWAS using the Gold-standard logistic regression model. The bias-corrected and the uncorrected Poisson models also captured these associations.
title: Overcome the Limitation of Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PheWAS): Extension of PheWAS to Efficient and Robust Large-Scale ICD Codes Analysis

finding: This SNP was identified as the most significant locus on chromosome 16 in the context of treatment-resistant depression (TRD) based on the MGB TRD meta-analysis, with a P-value of 4.3×10^-11. It had an inverse effect on body mass index (BMI), and was in high linkage disequilibrium (R2 = 1.0) with SNP rs9939609, which is strongly associated with BMI. The finding suggested shared biological pathways between BMI regulation and TRD.
title: Genome-wide association study of treatment resistant depression highlights shared biology with metabolic traits

finding: Although not directly studied in the TRD GWAS presented, this SNP was mentioned as being in high linkage disequilibrium with rs56313538, connecting it to BMI and weight regulation via IRX3 expression. It had a strong association with BMI (P = 1.95×10^-145), indicating a relevant metabolic pathway implicating this SNP in the context of TRD.
title: Genome-wide association study of treatment resistant depression highlights shared biology with metabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs16953809 was identified within the region 16q23.2, achieving suggestive significance for left unilateral cleft lip (LCL) with a p-value of 1.43 × 10-7. This finding was noted while analyzing the genetic distinctions between LCL from unaffected controls, indicating its potential role in increasing risk for this specific cleft subtype.
title: FAT4 Identified as a Potential Modifier of Orofacial Cleft Laterality

finding: The SNP rs27741 was identified as the most significant risk locus in the frailty GWAS, specifically linked to Factor 4, which pertains to metabolic and respiratory problems. This factor's pathways were enriched with genetic signals related to cell signaling and 16p11.2 distal deletion syndrome, a condition linked to severe developmental outcomes. The significant P-value associated with this SNP was 1.09×10−35, indicating a strong association with the frailty phenotype and suggesting that the underlying biology may be connected to genetic factors influencing frailty and related health declines.
title: Uncovering the multivariate genetic architecture of frailty with genomic structural equation modelling

finding: The rs41278174 SNP, which represented a missense variant (G>A) in exon 23 of the ABCC6 gene, was associated with elevated calcium and phosphate levels through SNP-GWAS. This variant was located near the copy number variation (CNV) region impacting kidney stone risk, where individuals with deletions in the ABCC6 gene showed a significantly increased prevalence of kidney stones (OR=5.9; p=7.3 x 10^-7). The finding connected the genetic variant to the pathogenicity associated with renal health and further elucidated the relation between the CNV affecting ABCC6 and its implication in calcium metabolism disorders.
title: Copy-number variants as modulators of common disease susceptibility

finding: This SNP mapped to the KCTD13 gene and exhibited multiple trans QTL effects influencing brain gene expressions such as YPEL3, MAPK3, and TBX6. It provided insights into the genetic nuances associated with hippocampal volumes and their link to AD.
title: Identification of novel associations of candidate loci with Alzheimer’s disease by leveraging the shared genetic basis with hippocampal volume

finding: The CETP variant -629C>A (rs1800775) was found to disrupt transcription factor binding and reduce CETP activity. It served as a strong predictor of genetically predicted lower CETP levels, associating with higher HDL-c levels and lower LDL-c levels. Specifically, a one standard deviation decrease in the genetic CETP score, which includes this variant, resulted in an increase of 0.167 standard deviations in HDL-c.
title: Study of effect modifiers of genetically predicted CETP reduction

finding: The study highlighted that the SNP rs11864587 was top-associated with an FEV1/FVC-related structural variant deletion in the intron of CFDP1 (Sniffles2.DEL.3639MF). The association was characterized by a p-value of 1.1×10^-65 and a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.413. Follow-up analyses provided strong evidence linking CFDP1 expression in fibroblasts to a lower FEV1/FVC measure, supporting its role in respiratory disease.
title: Imputation of structural variants using a multi-ancestry long-read sequencing panel enables identification of disease associations

finding: PLCG2:rs72824905-G was acknowledged for its protective qualities, adding valuable information about genetic resilience to AD.
title: Biobank-scale characterization of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias identifies potential disease-causing variants, risk factors, and genetic modifiers across diverse ancestries

finding: The study assessed the impact of PRS on the penetrance of the breast cancer risk variant c.1592delT (rs180177102) in PALB2. The context was within a recent study that evaluated breast cancer risk among the Finnish population.
title: Breast and prostate cancer risk: the interplay of polygenic risk, high-impact monogenic variants, and family history

finding: BCKDK rs14235 A allele was associated with milder motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients. Specifically, it significantly modified rigidity scores and Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale part III (UPDRS-III) scores, displaying a negative association with both (β = -1.0410, p < 0.01 for rigidity; β = -3.3540, p < 0.01 for UPDRS-III). Moreover, differential network metrics mediated the effects of BCKDK rs14235 on these motor symptoms.
title: BCKDK rs14235 A allele is associated with milder motor impairment and altered network topology in Parkinson’s disease

finding: The rs73550818 SNP in GOT2 was identified as having a protective effect against alcohol consumption in heterozygotes, and it was associated with increased expression of GOT2 in liver.
title: Genotype-stratified GWAS meta-analysis reveals novel loci associated with alcohol consumption

finding: The SNP rs9931086 in the SLC38A8 gene modified the effects of occupational exposures on FEV1, suggesting a role in susceptibility to the effects of cigarette smoke. Network analysis implicated inflammatory pathways involving CTLA-4, HDAC, and PPAR-alpha in these interactions.
title: Smoking Interaction with a Polygenic Risk Score for Reduced Lung Function

finding: FTO*rs17817964 showed a significant association with a p-value of 3.04×10−11, previously known for links to body mass index, possibly linking metabolic aspects to ocular health.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: Associated with FOXL1 and significantly linked to ERM, showing relevance in bone density and height while also suggesting a role in eye development.
title: Genomewide association study of epiretinal membrane: discovery of significant risk loci in each of three American populations

finding: The rs4888606 SNP was associated with MSW in CFSRS (p=9x10^-6) and with nonword reading (ALSPACread) in ALSPAC (p=0.046). This SNP is located within an intron of MON1B and serves as an meQTL for methylation markers cg06128999 and cg05007098, suggesting an important regulatory role in speech-related phenotypes.
