finding: In a Western Siberia population, the G allele of rs708272 was linked to lower levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol and higher atherogenic index, implicating its role in developing myocardial infarction (MI).
title: In-silico analysis of Myocardial Infarction-related missense SNPs to identify novel biomarkers to predict susceptibility

finding: The rs1421085 T-to-C single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) was found to be associated with an upregulation of EN1 in the obesity-prone phenotype of human adipocytes. This finding indicated a species-specific regulatory role of EN1 in the modulation of UCP1 expression, where EN1 was negatively correlated with UCP1 gene expression. The implications of this SNP relate to metabolic processes, particularly in the context of brown adipogenesis, suggesting that variations in this SNP can influence fat cell phenotypes and possibly metabolic disorders.
title: Deciphering Species-Specific and Conserved Regulation of Human UCP1 Gene Expression: Insights from Predicted Homeodomain Family Transcription Factor Binding Sites

finding: Located in the PIEZO1 gene, this missense variant was associated with higher hemoglobin concentration with a frequency of 3.65% in the XSA cohort, showing an effect of 0.36 standard deviations.
title: The sequences of 150,119 genomes in the UK biobank

finding: The rs1967309 SNP in the ADCY9 gene was associated with clinical responses to the CETP modulator dalcetrapib. Individuals with the AA genotype experienced fewer cardiovascular events and reduced atherosclerosis when treated with dalcetrapib compared to placebo. This finding was particularly significant in the Peruvian population, indicating the relevance of this SNP in cardiovascular health.
title: A sex-specific evolutionary interaction between ADCY9 and CETP

finding: The SNP rs158477 in the CETP gene was found to be in long-range linkage disequilibrium with rs1967309 in the Peruvian population. This relationship suggests a genetic interaction between ADCY9 and CETP, with implications for pharmacogenomic response to dalcetrapib. The combination of rs1967309-AA and rs158477-GG was linked to favorable cardiovascular outcomes in a sex-specific manner.
title: A sex-specific evolutionary interaction between ADCY9 and CETP

finding: The SNP rs759387263 was identified through gnomAD data analysis and was associated with splicing abnormalities in PABPN1L. It had a total of 26 carriers detected, suggesting a potential role in female infertility due to abnormal early embryonic development as evidenced by the sterile phenotype observed in Pabpn1l -/- mice.
title: Maternal factor PABPN1L is essential for maternal mRNA degradation during maternal-to-zygotic transition

finding: The SNP rs537683283 was also found to be recurrently detected near Exon2 of PABPN1L, indicating its potential impact on normal gene function. Its association with splicing abnormalities contributed to female infertility in the Pabpn1l -/- mouse model.
title: Maternal factor PABPN1L is essential for maternal mRNA degradation during maternal-to-zygotic transition

finding: Identified as a lead SNP for a previously reported locus associated with cIMT, emphasizing its role in cardiovascular risk.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: This SNP was considered in the context of previously reported loci associated with cIMT, supporting its relevance in cardiovascular disease.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: The rs1874459 SNP was associated with glaucoma and most accessible in rod bipolar cells, where it was predicted to act on CDH11. It introduced a new bHLH domain, facilitating interaction with NEUROD4, a transcription factor important in bipolar and amacrine cell development.
title: Single-cell multiome of the human retina and deep learning nominate causal variants in complex eye diseases

finding: Variant rs12927355 at chr16:11100914:C:T was identified to have acinar cell-specific effects on a cRE intronic to the CLEC16A gene. Similar to rs2253317, this variant also showed allele-specific interactions with transcription factors, contributing to insights into regulatory mechanisms in acinar cells.
title: Single cell multiome profiling of pancreatic islets reveals physiological changes in cell type-specific regulation associated with diabetes risk

finding: The rs72824905 variant, corresponding to a missense mutation P522R in the PLCG2 gene, was found to be significantly associated with increased risk for Alzheimer's Disease (AD) (p=0.047; OR=1.164 [95% CI=1.002-1.351]). This indicates that while a different rare variant in the same gene confers protection, this specific variant is linked with a heightened susceptibility to AD, suggesting a complex role of PLCG2 in AD pathophysiology.
title: PLCG2 as a Risk Factor for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The rs4420523 SNP was identified as the most significantly associated variant with PLCG2 expression levels in the superior temporal gyrus, showing a very low p-value (p=2.43E-06). Individuals carrying the C minor allele exhibited higher expression levels of PLCG2. This finding was further validated in the temporal cortex of the MAYO cohort and across various brain regions and other organs according to the GTEx eQTL database.
title: PLCG2 as a Risk Factor for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: SNP rs1646233 mapped to the gene CBFA2T3, which is involved in various genetic disorders.
title: Locating suspicious lethal genes by abnormal distributions of SNP patterns

finding: The SNP rs7198036, located in the CDH13 gene locus, was identified as a bQTL affecting TCF21 occupancy. It was confirmed that allele A had a higher TCF21 occupancy than allele G.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapped for TCF21 binding, chromatin accessibility and chromosomal looping in coronary artery smooth muscle cells reveal molecular mechanisms of coronary disease loci

finding: The caQTL and clQTL variant rs12444113, located approximately 10kb downstream of the CDH13 transcription start site, showed higher chromatin accessibility with the G allele compared to the C allele, indicating a long-range regulatory effect.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapped for TCF21 binding, chromatin accessibility and chromosomal looping in coronary artery smooth muscle cells reveal molecular mechanisms of coronary disease loci

finding: The SNP rs12102766 was identified in the context of targeted inhibition of the NUP98-NSD1 fusion oncogene in acute myeloid leukemia. The findings suggested that this SNP may play a role in the effectiveness of treatments aimed at this particular fusion gene, which is significant for understanding therapeutic strategies in AML.
title: Nanoparticle-mediated Targeting of the Fusion Gene RUNX1/ETO in t(8;21)-positive Acute Myeloid Leukaemia

finding: The SNP rs8057431 altered a PU.1 motif and was associated with a disruption in the binding of both PU.1 and C/EBPβ. This finding related to variations in transcription factor binding that could potentially influence immune system traits.
title: Variation in PU.1 binding and chromatin looping at neutrophil enhancers influences autoimmune disease susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs1728369 was assessed in the context of samples that were amplified with 15 PCR cycles. It was found in all but one of the samples analyzed, indicating successful recovery of known SNPs under conditions of reduced coverage. The improved performance in terms of recall (98.41%) and precision (84.05%) when using fewer amplification cycles demonstrated that lower coverage enhanced the ability to identify this SNP.
title: Accurate profiling of forensic autosomal STRs using the Oxford Nanopore Technologies MinION device

finding: This SNP was a stress-interactive eQTL regulating the KNOP1 gene in the MeA with traumatic stress, highlighting a specific interaction between genotype and stress exposure.
title: Common genetic variation impacts stress response in the brain

finding: The variant rs9039 was associated with sleep disorders (PheCode 327) and co-localized with an intronic A-to-G RNA editing site in the gene C16orf72. This finding suggested a relationship between the genetic variation at this locus and the editing process relevant to the pathophysiology of sleep disorders.
title: Expansion of RNA sequence diversity and RNA editing rates throughout human cortical development

finding: This SNP was associated with fatty acids and is situated in the PDXDC1 locus, approximately 23Kb from other SNPs like rs11075253 and rs11644601, which had previously been linked to fatty acids metabolism.
title: A computationally efficient Bayesian Seemingly Unrelated Regressions model for high-dimensional Quantitative Trait Loci discovery

finding: This SNP was associated with multiple metabolites linked to VLDL and is located near rs74249229, a SNP previously reported to be associated with similar traits.
title: A computationally efficient Bayesian Seemingly Unrelated Regressions model for high-dimensional Quantitative Trait Loci discovery

finding: This SNP was confirmed to have a known association with HDLs in the CEPT gene and was highlighted for its relevance to different lipoproteins.
title: A computationally efficient Bayesian Seemingly Unrelated Regressions model for high-dimensional Quantitative Trait Loci discovery

finding: This SNP was associated with multiple cholesterol-related phenotypes and was noted for uncovering potential important associations in the study.
title: A computationally efficient Bayesian Seemingly Unrelated Regressions model for high-dimensional Quantitative Trait Loci discovery

finding: rs1641047 was identified as a Tier 1 AFR_high-specific eQTL of the ABAT gene, which had been associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc) in a comparison study of European and African American patients. The T allele was common in African Americans (MAF = 0.04) but rare in Mexican Americans and Europeans.
title: Gene expression in African Americans and Latinos reveals ancestry-specific patterns of genetic architecture

finding: The allele frequency of the HNA-5 variant rs2230433 (ITGAL_chr16:30506720G>C) encoding the 5b allele was found to be highly prevalent at 78.2% in the Indian population. This frequency was comparable to that of South Asians at 65.6%, but significantly different when compared to other populations such as East Asians (14.3%), Latino Americans (25.7%), African-Americans (42.2%), European-Finnish (25.4%), European-non-Finnish (29.4%), Greater Middle Easterners (34.5%), Amish (30.2%) and Ashkenazi Jewish (31.4%). The finding underscores a significant distinction in prevalence of the HNA-5 variant in the Indian population compared to global trends.
title: Genetic landscape of Human neutrophil antigen variants in India from population-scale genomes

finding: The SNP rs1421085 was associated with obesity and showed strong evidence for a regulatory role. This evidence included eQTL associations with the genes IRX3 and FTO, chromatin looping, TF motifs, and overlap with DNase I hotspots and histone mark broadPeaks. The FORGEdb score of 9 indicated significant evidence for its functional relevance, consistent with experimental analyses demonstrating its influence on adipocyte proliferation involving IRX3.
title: FORGEdb: a tool for identifying candidate functional variants and uncovering target genes and mechanisms for complex diseases

finding: The SNP rs72812428 at chr16:46,906,797 was shown to be a common causal variant affecting the DNAm of cg14880584 and the expression of the GPT2 gene. This gene plays a role in gluconeogenesis, and significant hypermethylation of GPT2 was noted at both 30 minutes and 4 hours after a test meal. The under-regulation of GPT2 linked to the glucose iAUC of participants highlights the potential impact of this SNP on glucose metabolism postprandially.
title: DNA methylation and gene expression trajectories of human postprandial metabolism

finding: The SNP rs12102813 was identified in a study related to pediatric diffuse midline gliomas, particularly focusing on radio-resistance and DNA repair mechanisms. It was noted that this SNP may have implications for how tumor cells respond to therapeutic ionizing radiation, as the study linked genetic factors to the regulation of vital adaptive programs under stress, namely concerning DNA repair pathways.
title: Rapid PTEFb-dependent transcriptional reorganization underpins the glioma adaptive response to radiotherapy

finding: A mutation in the ADCY7 gene (rs77150043) was suggested to play a role in the early onset of psoriasis and Crohn's disease. This finding contributed to the understanding of how mutations in ADCY7 can influence the development of these autoimmune conditions, indicating a potential therapeutic target related to Th cell differentiation.
title: A forskolin-mediated increase in cAMP promotes T helper cell differentiation into the Th1 and Th2 subsets rather than into the Th17 subset

finding: Another mutation in the ADCY7 gene (rs78534766) was reported to double the risk of the development of ulcerative colitis. This finding emphasized the critical role of ADCY7 mutations in the deregulation of Th cell subpopulation balance, offering insights into the pathogenic mechanisms underlying ulcerative colitis.
title: A forskolin-mediated increase in cAMP promotes T helper cell differentiation into the Th1 and Th2 subsets rather than into the Th17 subset

finding: The SNP rs12102760 was associated with pH dynamics and its impact on transcriptional regulation. The research highlighted that altered intracellular pH could drive significant changes in gene expression, particularly in signaling pathways such as Notch1 and metabolic pathways involving lactate and pyruvate dehydrogenase. This connection indicates that genetic variants at this locus may influence an individual's susceptibility to cancer by modulating pHi dynamics.
title: Intracellular pH differentially regulates transcription of metabolic and signaling pathways in normal epithelial cells

finding: The SNP rs12051308 was found to be relevant in the context of high-grade TP53-specific subgroup characterization within ovarian granulosa cell tumors. The discovery emphasized the heterogeneity of tumors and how specific genetic markers like rs12051308 could relate to tumor classification and treatment approaches.
title: Nanopore-based consensus sequencing enables accurate multimodal tumor cell-free DNA profiling

finding: Associated with glutarylcarnitine (C5-DC) via ABCC1, showcasing its contribution to fatty acid metabolism pathways.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The SNP rs12051107 was associated with the IL-6/JAK/STAT3 signaling pathway, which played a crucial role in promoting non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) metastasis. This finding was part of a broader context indicating that PDE1A affected the STAT3 pathway, enhancing the aggressive characteristics of NSCLC. Additionally, the study uncovered that inhibiting PDE1A could sensitize NSCLC cells to cisplatin treatment, providing new insights into potential therapeutic interventions for patients dealing with NSCLC.
title: Phosphodiesterase 1A physically interacts with YTHDF2 and reinforces the progression of non-small cell lung cancer

finding: This variant in the CYP19A1 gene was found to have a strong association with dyslexia-related phenotypes based on comprehensive analysis across multiple studies. It indicated a genetic contribution to dyslexia, highlighting the role of regulatory variations affecting reading abilities.
title: Targeted analysis of dyslexia-associated regions on chromosomes 6, 12 and 15 in large multigenerational cohorts

finding: This SNP on FTO, demonstrated GWS association with smoking cessation, emphasizing the link between obesity and smoking cessation.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: This SNP near FTO showed significant association with smoking cessation, reinforcing the connection between metabolic processes and addictive behaviors.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: Previously recorded for its association with AC, this SNP on FTO confirmed its significance in both alcohol consumption and smoking behaviors.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: Another SNP near FTO that was linked to AUD, indicating overlapping genetic influences between alcohol use and smoking behavior.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The rs1421085 variant at the FTO locus was associated with genetic predisposition to obesity. This SNP was connected to IRX3's role in upregulating genes involved in adipogenesis, particularly influencing energy-storage mechanisms in mature adipocytes. This finding was further supported by studies showing that individuals carrying the obesity-risk allele for rs1421085 exhibited reduced thermogenic capacity in beige adipocytes.
title: Mechanisms of the FTO locus association with obesity: Irx3 controls a sumoylation-dependent switch between adipogenesis and osteogenesis

finding: The SNP rs12102938 was discussed in the context of a study conducted by Siraj et al. in 2020, where it was implicated in the clonal evolution and timing of metastatic colorectal cancer. The research provided insights into how this genetic variant could relate to cancer progression and metastasis, which is crucial for understanding the dynamics of colorectal cancer.
title: Visual Clustering of Transcriptomic Data from Primary and Metastatic Tumors – Dependencies and Novel Pitfalls

finding: The SNP rs3785098 was identified as having significant regulatory effects in both HepG2 and K562 cells. It was associated with levels of HDL cholesterol, indicating a potential role in cholesterol regulation and related metabolic pathways.
title: High-throughput functional analysis of IncRNA core promoters elucidatesrules governing tissue-specificity

finding: The A allele at rs12922757 was found to increase the expression of the Growth Arrest Specific 8 gene (GAS8) specifically in individuals with perceived high socio-economic status. This finding indicated a protective effect against asthma, as higher GAS8 expression was correlated with reduced disease risk, illustrating the interplay between genetics and socio-economic factors in the context of asthma risk.
title: Psychosocial experiences modulate asthma-associated genes through gene-environment interactions

finding: The SNP rs12051172 was associated with AATF expression levels in human HCC tissues. Higher AATF expression correlated with advanced stages and tumor grades of HCC, indicating its potential role in angiogenesis regulation. Further analysis revealed that inhibition of AATF in HCC cells resulted in increased levels of PEDF, leading to reduced angiogenesis, which was crucial in the study's findings relating to tumor growth and metastasis.
title: AATF Inhibition Exerts Antiangiogenic Effects Against Human Hepatocellular Carcinoma

finding: The study indicated that the SNP rs12102727 was associated with differential drug sensitivity in models of colorectal cancer (CRC) and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). Specifically, the findings suggested that this SNP could serve as a biomarker for responses to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) treatment, revealing its significance in personalized medicine approaches within these cancer models.
title: Comparing in vitro cytotoxic drug sensitivity in colon and pancreatic cancer using 2D and 3D cell models: contrasting viability and growth inhibition in clinically relevant dose and repeated drug cycles

finding: The rs3809627 SNP on chromosome 16 was associated with trans-mQTL effects, specifically the CpG cg27018912 located in a CpG island on chromosome 4 affecting PRDM8 expression. The trans-mQTL effect was replicated across three independent datasets, establishing its link with MS susceptibility and identifying PRDM8 as a potential downstream target.
title: Impact of genetic susceptibility to multiple sclerosis on the T cell epigenome: proximal and distal effects

finding: The rs34590044-A allele, an AMH-specific mutation that emerged approximately 981,916 years ago, was significantly associated with increased height and basal metabolic rate (BMR) in humans. This variant enhanced the expression of the gene ACSF3, improving mitochondrial function and affecting body length and energy expenditure, particularly in threonine-enriched dietary conditions. The findings indicated a genetic adaptation contributing to the shift from a herbivorous diet to a carnivorous one in anatomically modern humans (AMHs).
title: Early to Middle Pleistocene transition shapes the evolution of human-specific mutations associated with height and basal metabolic rate

finding: The SNP rs3814877 was associated with changes in DNA methylation levels linked to schizophrenia, specifically influencing the gene YPEL3 as identified through the CEWAS method.
title: Cascading Epigenomic Analysis for Identifying Disease Genes from the Regulatory Landscape of GWAS Variants

finding: The SNP rs12051339 was identified as a positive finding related to the regulation of Src Family Kinases during colorectal cancer development. This finding underscored the significance of this genetic variant within the context of cancer progression, specifically highlighting its association with key processes involved in angiogenesis and cellular maintenance as demonstrated by related RNA-seq analyses.
title: N-VEGF, a proteolytic product of the long isoform of VEGF-A, L-VEGF, shuttles to the nucleus to activate cellular stress survival circuits

finding: The SNP rs75431978 demonstrated significant selection pressure within the SNX29 gene, indicating that this region underwent positive selection in the Han Chinese population, with a derived allele frequency (DAF) of 0.176 and a strong p-value of 1.31 × 10^-15.
title: Genomic analyses of 10,376 individuals provides comprehensive map of genetic variations, structure and reference haplotypes for Chinese population

finding: The rs9927852 variant had a significant eQTL for MAF and exhibited interaction effects with continuous cell states, specifically impacting eQTL strength in relation to CV1 scores, reinforcing its importance in the context of immune variation.
title: Modeling memory T cell states at single-cell resolution identifies in vivo state-dependence of eQTLs influencing disease

finding: This SNP was located in the regulatory region of the gene MAF, which plays a role in pancreatic development and regulates insulin gene transcription. Its association with insulin secretion suggests a critical role in glucose metabolism, particularly relevant during periods of dietary transition.
title: 1,000 ancient genomes uncover 10,000 years of natural selection in Europe

finding: Located in the HYDIN gene, this splice mutation was linked to primary ciliary dyskinesia-5, impacting sperm motility and leading to male infertility. Its detection highlighted reproductive adaptations influenced by environmental factors.
title: 1,000 ancient genomes uncover 10,000 years of natural selection in Europe

finding: The SNP rs185353598, located in the exonic region of CTU2, was found to be pleiotropic with HbA1c. This finding was noted as novel and emphasizes its potential relevance in understanding associations with diabetes-related traits.
title: Causal inference for multiple risk factors and diseases from genomics data

finding: The rs13329835 variant was discovered in the intergenic region of the CDYL2 gene and was associated with breast cancer progression, highlighting its potential in cancer therapeutic strategies.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The rs9940301 variant was significantly associated with breast cancer, influencing the expression of CDYL2 through physical interactions with enhancers.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs423984 was implicated in the regulation of FOXL1 gene expression, which is associated with myocardial infarction and coronary artery calcification (CAC). It was found to be in an enhancer region overlapping known CAD risk variants, highlighting its potential role in vascular remodeling and disease through its involvement with downstream genes influenced by FHL5.
title: FHL5 controls vascular disease-associated gene programs in smooth muscle cells

finding: The SNP rs12102865 was recognized as a significant finding in the context of follicular lymphoma (FL). The study examined the integrative analysis of cell crosstalk within the FL cell niche and concluded that this SNP may contribute to defining the supportive synapse which is critical for the development and progression of this subtype of B-NHL.
title: Stromal cells regulate malignant B-cell spatial organization, survival, and drug response in a new 3D model mimicking lymphoma tumor niche

finding: The SNP rs1231123 represented a missense mutation within the region spanning from intron 2 to 3' UTR of the <italic>MEFV</italic> gene. It was noted for being predicted under selection in European populations, with characteristics suggesting its potential role in modulating susceptibility to Familial Mediterranean Fever. This finding stemmed from the deployment of a trained deep neural network, which identified it as a variant under incomplete sweep.
title: Distinguishing between recent balancing selection and incomplete sweep using deep neural networks

finding: The SNP rs1231122 was identified as a stop-gained mutation depending on the corresponding isoform in the haplotype block from intron 2 to 3' UTR of the <italic>MEFV</italic> gene. Similar to rs1231123, it was predicted to be under selection, implicating its possible relevance in susceptibility to Familial Mediterranean Fever, driven by historical adaptations to pathogens. The identification was supported by results from a convolutional neural network applied to genomic data from European populations.
title: Distinguishing between recent balancing selection and incomplete sweep using deep neural networks

finding: In a study involving over 15,000 individuals, it was identified that the SNP rs4888378, located in the last 3' intron of CFDP1, was associated with carotid intima-media thickness (cIMT), which is a known marker for subclinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. This finding highlighted the significance of CFDP1 in cardiovascular risk.
title: Cfdp1 is Essential for Cardiac Development and Function

finding: Through an analysis of data from the UK Biobank and the CARDIoGRAMplusC4D 1000 Genomes imputation study, the SNP rs3851738 was identified as CAD-associated. Additionally, a phenome-wide association study (PheWas) correlated this variant with systolic blood pressure, further elucidating the role of CFDP1 in cardiovascular health.
title: Cfdp1 is Essential for Cardiac Development and Function

finding: The SNP rs1558902, noted as the genetic variant with the largest effect on BMI, was included in further analysis to assess BMI effects without the influence of pleiotropy. Although described as likely to have low statistical power, it was positioned to yield insights into the causal relationships between BMI and socioeconomic factors.
title: Effects of body mass index on relationship status, social contact, and socioeconomic position: Mendelian Randomization study in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs12102739 was originally identified in the context of its association with cancer, specifically linked to the role of the POT1 protein in human cancer as described in the study by Wu et al. (2020). This SNP was shown to be related to variations in POT1 function, which is critical for telomere protection and may influence cancer susceptibility.
title: POT1 Stability and Binding Measured by Fluorescence Thermal Shift Assays

finding: The rs1143679 SNP was identified as a risk variant for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and lupus nephritis (LN). This variant was shown to produce less active CD11b protein, correlating with significantly elevated serum levels of type I interferon (IFN-I) in SLE patients. Additionally, patients with the rs1143679 risk allele of the ITGAM gene exhibited significantly higher levels of soluble urokinase plasminogen activator receptor (suPAR), linking decreased CD11b activity to increased kidney disease risk.
title: CD11b suppresses TLR7-driven inflammatory signaling to protect against lupus nephritis

finding: The SNP rs7190785 at the GRIN2A locus was associated with increased FV activity among heterozygous carriers of rs75463553-T, indicating a gene-gene interaction affecting FV levels and further regional genetic regulation.
title: A genome wide search for non-additive allele effects identifies PSKH2 as involved in the variability of Factor V activity

finding: The SNP rs9937053 was the lead variant located intronically near the FTO gene on chromosome 16 with an exceptionally significant association with OSA, P = 4.3 x 10^-16. This finding reinforced the connection between obesity-related loci and OSA, as FTO has been previously associated with body mass index (BMI) as well.
title: Genetic analysis of obstructive sleep apnoea discovers a strong association with cardiometabolic health

finding: The SNP rs2002833 was identified as an index SNP at locus 16q24.3 related to varicose veins (VVs), marking it as a significant genetic factor influencing the disease.
title: Genome-wide association analysis and replication in 810,625 individuals identifies novel therapeutic targets for varicose veins

finding: The SNP rs7184427, causing a predicted deleterious p.Val250Ala substitution within the PIEZO1 gene, was associated with varicose veins (VVs) with a P-value of 9.10×10^-40 and an odds ratio of 1.19.
title: Genome-wide association analysis and replication in 810,625 individuals identifies novel therapeutic targets for varicose veins

finding: The study indicated that rs12102910 was associated with an increased vulnerability in IDH1<sup>mut</sup> gliomas, specifically regarding sphingolipid metabolism. This finding contributed to the understanding of IDH1<sup>mut</sup> oligodendroglioma pathology, linking genetic variance to the responsiveness of glioma cells to therapies targeting acid ceramidase.
title: Targeting IDH1-Mutated Oligodendroglioma with Acid Ceramidase Inhibitors

finding: Located on hsa-miR-5189-3p, the G allele significantly altered the hairpin's secondary structure, affecting maturation; none of the MARTHA individuals expressing the G allele expressed the alternative sequence.
title: OPTIMIR, a novel algorithm for integrating available genome-wide genotype data into miRNA sequence alignment analysis

finding: Among 65 heterozygous individuals for this SNP linked with hsa-miR-7854-3p, 54 only expressed the alternative version, with the others showing a mean ratio favoring the alternative allele.
title: OPTIMIR, a novel algorithm for integrating available genome-wide genotype data into miRNA sequence alignment analysis

finding: The study reported for the first time an association between the T-allele in rs9923231 of the VKORC1 gene and increased risk for vascular dementia (OR=1.28, p=0.0069). The association was not present for general dementia or Alzheimer's dementia, indicating a specific link to vascular dementia.
title: Variation in VKORC1 is associated with vascular dementia

finding: The SNP rs3812963 was identified within the metallothionein gene cluster on chromosome 16 and was significantly associated with delayed age of onset in Huntington disease (HD). This relationship was established through comprehensive mega-analysis combining data from HD patient cohorts, suggesting that this SNP acts as an expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) correlated with increased metallothionein levels in the prefrontal cortex.
title: Multi-OMIC analysis of Huntington disease reveals a neuroprotective astrocyte state

finding: The SNP rs74611520 was also located in the metallothionein gene cluster and was significantly associated with delayed age of onset in HD. Like rs3812963, it was found to act as an eQTL, associated with increased metallothionein levels, thereby linking it to potential protective mechanisms against neurodegeneration in HD.
title: Multi-OMIC analysis of Huntington disease reveals a neuroprotective astrocyte state

finding: The SNP rs2518054, located within the same metallothionein gene cluster, was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with the other identified SNPs and was significantly associated with delayed age of onset in HD. This further highlighted the importance of the metallothionein locus in influencing the clinical progression of HD.
title: Multi-OMIC analysis of Huntington disease reveals a neuroprotective astrocyte state

finding: The lead variant rs2008514 was associated with the ATXN2L-221 isoform, resulting in structural changes linked to intelligence phenotypes. It was part of a strong LD network affecting various isoforms.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The rs55719896 variant was in strong LD with rs2008514 and was implicated in alternative splicing affecting ATXN2L, with differential expression patterns related to intelligence.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: The effective allele rs8062405-G decreased the expression of ATXN2L-211 in association with intelligence, indicating a complex relationship between multiple isoforms and their phenotypic impacts.
title: Splicing QTL analysis focusing on coding sequences reveals pathogenicity of disease susceptibility loci

finding: Identified as an eSNP for MC1R, rs117406136 was involved in a trans regulatory network affecting several genes, linking pigmentation-related genetic variation to immunomodulatory functions in NK cells.
title: Natural Killer cells demonstrate distinct eQTL and transcriptome-wide disease associations, highlighting their role in autoimmunity

finding: This SNP, which encodes a non-synonymous polymorphism within MC1R, showed a significant allele-specific expression pattern that linked pigmentation and immunological responses, demonstrating its relevance in NK cell immunology.
title: Natural Killer cells demonstrate distinct eQTL and transcriptome-wide disease associations, highlighting their role in autoimmunity

finding: The rs72785165 was found to be associated with HbA1c levels in the chr16:68755635 locus, acting through an eASQTL for CDH3 isoform, hypothesized to influence glucose control.
title: eQTL mapping in fetal-like pancreatic progenitor cells reveals early developmental insights into diabetes risk

finding: The rs4783565 was linked to HbA1c levels and shown to be in high LD with rs72785165, which plays a role in alternative splicing of CDH3 influencing insulin secretion.
title: eQTL mapping in fetal-like pancreatic progenitor cells reveals early developmental insights into diabetes risk

finding: The study reported that the rs1421085 T-to-C SNP in the FTO gene was associated with an obesity-risk phenotype. Donors with CC alleles exhibited a shift in adipocyte differentiation from beige (active thermogenic) to white (lipid-storing), leading to lower expression of thermogenic genes such as UCP1, PM20D1, and CIDEA in active beige adipocytes. In contrast, TT carriers demonstrated higher thermogenic capacity and higher expression of thermogenic markers, suggesting the SNP's critical role in energy regulation within adipose tissues.
title: Human Abdominal Subcutaneous-Derived Active Beige Adipocytes Carrying FTO rs1421085 Obesity-Risk Alleles Exert Lower Thermogenic Capacity

finding: There was a key relationship reported with rs8060054, showing that variants influencing RNF43 impacted Wnt receptor turnover and were dysregulated in cancer, contributing to altered signaling pathways in melanoma.
title: RNF43 inhibits WNT5A driven signaling and suppresses melanoma invasion

finding: The SNP rs529866, associated with the LITAF locus, showed distinct accessible chromatin peaks in macrophages. This region's activity was linked to the anti-TNFα response, demonstrating a decrease in inflamed vs. noninflamed tissue. The expression of LITAF in inflamed macrophages was significantly elevated, indicating a potential role in IBD pathophysiology.
title: Accessible chromatin maps of inflammatory bowel disease intestine nominate cell-type mediators of genetic disease risk

finding: The study confirmed that the SNP rs12102876 had a positive and original finding related to the blockage of store-operated Ca2+ influx through inhibition of the Orai1 channel, which is crucial in B-cell function, particularly in B-cell cancers. The research illustrated its connection to alterations in Ca2+ signaling that affect the survival of primary B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (B-CLL) cells.
title: Blocking Orai1 constitutive activity inhibits B-cell cancer migration and synergistically acts with drugs to reduce B-CLL cell survival

finding: The non-risk allele of rs9922678 in the GRIN2A gene was found under positive selection, lasting approximately 25,237 years. This SNP also exhibited a high correlation (ρ = 0.92) with PFS-26 of ST8SIA2, indicating its significance in global adaptations concerning psychosocial stress.
title: Global adaptive evolution involved in neuroticism and educational behaviors through the spread of anatomically modern humans

finding: SNP rs546055 was linked with cancer risk, survival, and ICB response, demonstrating its multifaceted impact on tumor progression and immunotherapy efficacy.
title: Germline modifiers of the tumor immune microenvironment implicate drivers of cancer risk and immunotherapy response

finding: The SNP rs12103023 was connected to NRF2 signaling pathways. Its relevance was noted in the context of metabolic processes in cancers, supporting the idea that variations associated with this SNP may alter metabolic responses in PDAC, enhancing the effectiveness of therapies that exploit changes in cellular redox state and glutamine metabolism.
title: PGM3 inhibition Shows cooperative Effects With Erastin inducing Pancreatic cancer cell death via activation of the Unfolded Protein Response

finding: The SNP rs12597281 was found to serve as an eQTL for the gene ACSF3 in rotenone-stimulated serotonergic neurons at day 52, but not in unstimulated conditions. ACSF3 encodes a mitochondrial acyl-CoA synthetase, and inherited mutations in this gene have been linked to combined malonic and methylmalonic aciduria (CMAMMA), which presents various neurological symptoms.
title: Population-scale single-cell RNA-seq profiling across dopaminergic neuron differentiation

finding: The alternate allele for SNP rs9939609 was associated with shorter telomeres, corroborating the influence of this genetic variation on aging processes.
title: Markers, Mechanisms and Metrics of Biological Aging: A Scoping Review

finding: SNP rs1985372 in the CLEC16A locus was significant in both KKNMS and IMSGC GWAS for MS, and DeepWAS linked it to alterations in several TF bindings, enhancing understanding of its regulatory role.
title: DeepWAS: Multivariate genotype-phenotype associations by directly integrating regulatory information using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs2286974 was in complete linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs1985372 and significant in the IMSGC GWAS for MS, implicating it in disease mechanisms alongside regulatory insights provided by DeepWAS.
title: DeepWAS: Multivariate genotype-phenotype associations by directly integrating regulatory information using deep learning

finding: SNP rs34286592 was noted as a top-associated locus in KKNMS GWAS for MS and was related to deepSNP rs175714's effects on TF binding, providing key insights into its regulatory role.
title: DeepWAS: Multivariate genotype-phenotype associations by directly integrating regulatory information using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs2230126 fell within an alternative promoter of the TAF1C gene and was classified as a fine-mapped human regulatory variant. Its orthologue in cattle was the leading eVariant for TAF1C expression in Nellore muscle, indicating conservation of regulatory effects across species.
title: The conservation of human functional variants and their effects across mammals

finding: The rs59735493 variant was associated with the <italic>KAT8</italic> locus and was linked to the integrins <italic>ITGAX</italic> and <italic>ITGAM</italic> in microglia. This variant was also indicated by a long-range eQTL association in peripheral blood.
title: Cell type-specific enhancer-promoter connectivity maps in the human brain and disease risk association

finding: The variant rs11865131 was identified as a functional variant using the malacoda method in the Ulirsch dataset with DeepSea-based conditional priors. This SNP is located within an intron of the NPRL3 gene, which encodes the Natriuretic Peptide Receptor Like 3 protein, involved in the GATOR1 complex that regulates the mTOR pathway. Analysis showed that rs11865131 colocalizes with ENCODE ChIP-Seq peaks for 36 transcription factors in K562 erytholeukemia cells and contains histone marks indicative of enhancers. Additionally, it was found associated with platelet NPRL3 mRNA levels, suggesting its relevance in regulating megakaryocyte and platelet development. The finding highlighted that malacoda successfully identified this variant, whereas it was missed by other MPRA analysis methods.
title: Bayesian modelling of high-throughput sequencing assays with malacoda

finding: The study mentioned the SNP rs12102876 in relation to the functionality of CRAC channels and the blockage of store-operated Ca(2+) influx by Synta66, indicating that Synta66 directly inhibited the Ca(2+) selective Orai1 pore. This finding suggested a genetic influence on the effectiveness of CRAC channel inhibitors and their potential role in modulating intracellular calcium levels, which is relevant for understanding autoimmune diseases.
title: Re-evaluation of some popular CRAC channel inhibitors – structurally similar but mechanistically different?

finding: The SNP rs35342456 was implicated as a functional candidate at the 16p13 DEXI/SOCS1 locus, linked to T1D risk. It had significant allelic effects on transcription factor binding (P=2.4×10^-5) in cytokine-induced beta cell cCREs. The risk allele showed preferential binding to transcription factors in electrophoretic mobility shift assays, indicating regulatory effects in beta cells, and it co-accessed with the SOCS1 promoter, which was up-regulated in cytokine treatment and associated with beta cell survival.
title: Type 1 diabetes risk genes mediate pancreatic beta cell survival in response to proinflammatory cytokines

finding: The rs72824905 variant in the PLCG2 gene, which results in the p.P522R amino acid change, was identified as a protective genetic variant associated with a reduced risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD). This variant functionally enhanced the role of the Plcγ2 enzyme in immune cells, leading to improved survival, heightened phagocytic activity, and increased acute inflammatory responses in macrophages derived from knock-in mice. Additionally, this variant was also associated with lower risks for other neurodegenerative diseases and a higher likelihood of longevity.
title: The Alzheimer’s disease-associated protective Plcγ2-P522R variant promotes beneficial microglial functions

finding: The TNRC6A variant (rs3803716) was identified among negatively selected variants, contributing to immune response traits.
title: Genetic adaptation to pathogens and increased risk of inflammatory disorders in post-Neolithic Europe

finding: The rs6564851-T allele was associated with increased BCO1 activity, leading to a reduction in total cholesterol and non-HDL-C compared to those with two copies of the rs6564851-G variant. This variant was also linked to triglyceride levels in middle-aged individuals, highlighting the role of BCO1 in regulating plasma lipid profiles. These findings demonstrate the clinical relevance of BCO1 and its activity in lipid metabolism, particularly in the context of dietary beta-carotene and its effects on cardiovascular health.
title: β-carotene accelerates the resolution of atherosclerosis in mice

finding: The rs199883290 (duplicated C) allele in the NOD2 gene strongly correlated (R>0.9) with the presence of the Lederbergvirus genus of phages, and simultaneously with the bacterial hosts Escherichia and Shigella. The NOD2 gene is crucial for pathogen recognition and immune response.
title: Triadic Dynamics of Gastric Bacterial Microbiome, Phageome, and Host Genotype, with Implications for Disease Associations

finding: The SNP rs8056814 in the CTRB1 locus was associated with four retinal edQTLs that colocalized with AMD. Two specific edSites (16:75445426 and 16:75445433) exhibited decreased editing with the disease risk allele, while two others (16:75445570 and 16:75446123) showed increased editing.
title: The retinal RNA editome is concentrated in photoreceptor-specific genes and genetically linked to vision loss

finding: The M28L variant (rs61749044) was identified as a loss-of-function variant associated with increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Its expression in mouse brain correlated with a transcriptomic profile characteristic of human AD modules.
title: Multi-omics analyses reveal novel effects of PLCγ2 deficiency in the mouse brain

finding: The P522R variant (rs72824905) was characterized as a protective functional hypermorph variant. This SNP increased the likelihood of longevity and was also associated with reduced risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD).
title: Multi-omics analyses reveal novel effects of PLCγ2 deficiency in the mouse brain

finding: Associated with recurrent kidney stones and linked to urine crystallization regulation, rs35747824 was found to be situated within the UMOD gene on 16p12.3.
title: GWAS identifies nine nephrolithiasis susceptibility loci related with metabolic metabolic and crystallization pathways

finding: The rs2230739 polymorphism of AC9 was associated with differences in susceptibility to drug treatment in asthma patients, highlighting AC9 as a potential target for asthma medications.
title: Structural basis of adenylyl cyclase 9 activation

finding: The study analyzed the role of the SNP rs4774 in the MHC2TA gene and its association with active replication of HHV-6A in patients with multiple sclerosis. The findings suggested that the presence of this SNP was linked to an increased likelihood of HHV-6A active replication in these patients, indicating a potential genetic predisposition influencing the virulence of HHV-6A in neurological conditions such as multiple sclerosis.
title: Differential susceptibility of neuronal neurotransmitter phenotypes to HHV6 infection

finding: SNP rs12102760 was connected to pH dynamics in cancer within the research published by Czowski et al. (2020). This study highlighted the relevance of transcriptional regulation regarding pH, further emphasizing the importance of molecular tools in understanding metabolic changes related to tumor development.
title: Computational investigation of missense somatic mutations in cancer and potential links to pH-dependence and proteostasis

finding: FTO rs9939609 was identified as the SNP most strongly associated with risk of being overweight. An A allele was linked to an average increase in body mass index (BMI) of 0.3 kg/m2. Although this SNP was regarded as significant, the likelihood of it affecting an individual's BMI was found to be only about 3% for single A allele carriers and 7% for homozygotes. Additionally, the overall contribution of FTO genotype to BMI variability was estimated at only 0.4%, indicating that environmental factors played a more dominant role.
title: Using synthetic datasets to better understand and explain health outcomes associated with common single nucleotide polymorphisms

finding: Alleles associated with red hair, specifically rs1805007/T, were present in 8.3% of EAJ. This prevalence was noted to be lower than the 12.4% found in MAJ, indicating a shared genetic trait but differing frequency between these populations.
title: Genome-wide data from medieval German Jews show that the Ashkenazi founder event pre-dated the 14th century

finding: Similarly, the rs1805008/T allele, part of the red hair phenotype, had an occurrence of 8.3% within EAJ, contrasting with 12.4% in MAJ. This highlighted a decrease in frequency among the medieval population while still indicating its presence.
title: Genome-wide data from medieval German Jews show that the Ashkenazi founder event pre-dated the 14th century

finding: The rs1805009/C allele was also identified among the EAJ at a rate of 8.3%, similar to the previous findings for other red hair alleles. This reiterates the concept that while these alleles existed in medieval populations, their frequencies were lower compared to modern samples.
title: Genome-wide data from medieval German Jews show that the Ashkenazi founder event pre-dated the 14th century

finding: The SNP rs12932935 was located in an intronic region of Rbfox1, which was noted as the most melted gene 14 days after cocaine exposure. Its melting score significantly increased from 43 at one day post-exposure to 125 at 14 days. This finding suggested that rs12932935 may play a role in the long-term structural reorganization of chromatin following cocaine exposure, potentially influencing gene expression related to cocaine sensitivity and addiction.
title: A single dose of cocaine rewires the 3D genome structure of midbrain dopamine neurons

finding: rs77924615 was reported as another putative functional regulatory variant identified through fine-mapping and colocalization analyses. In high-quality samples, this variant was associated with an open-chromatin peak that was well aligned, while low-quality samples frequently failed to detect such peaks at this locus.
title: Quality assessment and refinement of chromatin accessibility data using a sequence-based predictive model

finding: The SNP rs9928842 was associated with gene expression changes related to the HsInv0030 region, with an LD value of r^2 = 0.75, though its significance was lower compared to other variants.
title: Functional and evolutionary impact of polymorphic inversions in the human genome

finding: This SNP was linked to gene expression changes in the vicinity of HsInv0030, showing an LD value of r^2 = 0.73, indicating its role in eQTL associations.
title: Functional and evolutionary impact of polymorphic inversions in the human genome

finding: The SNP rs2937145 was found to be in almost perfect LD (r^2 = 0.98) with HsInv0031, which was associated with decreased expression of the FAM92B gene, further connected to Alzheimer's disease risk.
title: Functional and evolutionary impact of polymorphic inversions in the human genome

finding: rs1421085 had a causal and experimentally validated association with body mass index (BMI), being located in the FTO gene, which regulates IRX5 and IRX3. This SNP was extremely constrained in mammals with a phyloP score of 6.31, leading to a higher PIP score (0.84) when using the baseline-LF+Zoonomia model compared to non-functional models.
title: Leveraging Base Pair Mammalian Constraint to Understand Genetic Variation and Human Disease

finding: The SNP rs12051089 was associated with the study's examination of combined immunotherapy involving PD-1/PD-L1 antibodies and VEGF inhibitors in advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The findings suggested a positive correlation between this genetic variant and the response to combined immunotherapy strategies in HCC patients.
title: Cancer cell genetics shaping of the tumor microenvironment reveals myeloid cell-centric exploitable vulnerabilities in hepatocellular carcinoma

finding: The SNP rs12103023 was associated with the anti-oxidant response in the context of hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC). It was identified as a part of a network influenced by the transcription factor FOXA2. The research indicated that this SNP played a role in regulating anti-oxidant genes independent of NRF2, highlighting its significance in the molecular mechanisms responding to fumarate accumulation in FH-deficient cells.
title: FOXA2 controls the anti-oxidant response in FH-deficient cells

finding: The SNP rs8062895 was characterized as an intronic variant of DHODH, which had been previously implicated in cholesterol traits, thus linking it to lipid levels.
title: Genetically regulated gene expression underlies lipid traits in Hispanic cohorts

finding: The SNP rs12921479 was reported to be associated with Parkinson disease (PD) with a significance level of P = 9.31 × 10^-07 in an autopsy-confirmed cohort, indicating a strong link. This variant was identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the gene TRAPPC2L in the brain, which is known to be involved in neuronal functions and implicated in neurodevelopmental disorders. Although in subsequent meta-analysis the association was only nominally significant with P = 1.01 × 10^-02, the original finding in the autopsy-confirmed cohort supports the potential relevance of this SNP in the context of PD.
title: Overlapping Genetic Architecture between Parkinson Disease and Melanoma

finding: Regulatory potential was confirmed for this SNP regarding CFDP1 expression, with a significant reduction observed in gene levels post-CRISPRi.
title: Comprehensive identification of coronary artery disease-associated variants regulating vascular smooth muscle cell gene expression

finding: The SNP rs3198697 was linked to the expression of NPIPA5, a gene shown to have differential expression in multiple sclerosis patients. The T allele was associated with NPIPA5 being switched on across tissues, while the C allele correlated with the gene being switched off. This SNP elucidated the switch-like behavior of NPIPA5, which was co-expressed not only in blood and brain but also across other tissue pairs.
title: Switch-like Gene Expression Modulates Disease Susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs201525245 was identified as an eQTL affecting PKD1P5, with the C allele associated with the gene being switched on and the G allele with it being switched off. This finding contributed to understanding the switch-like expression characteristic of PKD1P5 and provided insights into regulatory mechanisms governing this gene's activity.
title: Switch-like Gene Expression Modulates Disease Susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs12051094 showed a significant association with the effects of beta-blockers on melanoma microenvironment and disease survival. This research underscored the importance of beta-blockers in modifying the tumor microenvironment, thereby impacting overall survival in melanoma patients.
title: Intracranial tumors elicit systemic sympathetic hyperactivity that limits immunotherapeutic responses

finding: The SNP rs11648785 displayed associations with DNAm sites influencing pigmentation traits, supporting its role in understanding skin cancer risks.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs1805005 was associated with various DNAm sites, highlighting its involvement in pigmentation-related traits.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs1805007 was linked to DNAm changes and was identified as a loss-of-function variant associated with red hair color and increased skin cancer risk.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs1805008 displayed strong associations with DNAm variations, reinforcing its significance as a pigmentation variant.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs2228479 was strongly associated with DNAm sites, marking its relevance in the study of fair skin traits and melanoma risk.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs258322 demonstrated associations with DNAm that relate to pigmentation traits, enhancing the understanding of its involvement in skin cancer.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs4785763 exhibited a relationship with DNAm changes linked to pigmentation and melanoma susceptibility.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs885479 was shown to have significant associations with DNAm sites impacting red hair pigmentation.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs34357723 was linked to DNAm changes related to red hair pigmentation, emphasizing its role as a significant genetic variant.
title: Investigating DNA methylation as a potential mediator between pigmentation genes, pigmentary traits and skin cancer

finding: The SNP rs12102773 was associated with altered levels of tRNA-derived small RNAs (tsRNAs) and miRNAs in males with high childhood maltreatment exposure (CME). This finding suggested that high CME influences epigenetic regulation through such small RNAs, which can have implications for the central nervous system development in subsequent generations.
title: Exposure to childhood maltreatment is associated with changes in sperm small non-coding RNA and DNA methylation profiles

finding: The study indicated that rs1985872 showed significantly higher expression with the reference alleles compared to alternate alleles, marking it as a candidate causal variant for SLE and several other autoimmune diseases.
title: Massively Parallel Reporter Assay Confirms Regulatory Potential of hQTLs and Reveals Important Variants in Lupus and Other Autoimmune Diseases

finding: Similar to rs1985872, this variant also produced significant expression results, prioritizing it as a potential causal variant for SLE and associated autoimmune conditions.
title: Massively Parallel Reporter Assay Confirms Regulatory Potential of hQTLs and Reveals Important Variants in Lupus and Other Autoimmune Diseases

finding: The genetic variant rs2000999 was previously associated with haptoglobin levels and diabetic macrovascular diseases specifically in a cohort of Chinese patients with type 2 diabetes. This indicates that the SNP may be implicated in the underlying mechanisms of diabetes-related complications.
title: BMI-CNV: A Bayesian framework for multiple genotyping platforms detection of copy number variation

finding: In the context of AUDIT-C, rs9937709 SNPs were found to be GWS before correction for BMI, emphasizing its role in alcohol-related traits.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Alcohol Consumption and Use Disorder in Multiple Populations (N = 274,424)

finding: Found to be significant for AUD, rs11075992's association remained notable even after correction for BMI, corroborating its relevance to alcohol use disorders.
title: Genome-wide Association Study of Alcohol Consumption and Use Disorder in Multiple Populations (N = 274,424)

finding: The SNP rs7196853, associated with the RIPOR1 gene at 16q22.1, demonstrated a strong link to the ratio of FEV1 to forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC) with a p-value of 1.3×10^-16. This finding contributed to understanding genetic factors influencing lung function.
title: Immune-mediated genetic pathways resulting in pulmonary function impairment increase lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs750739 in the PIEZO1 gene was linked to FEV1 with a p-value of 1.8×10^-10. This finding highlighted the role of mechanosensory ion channels in pulmonary function, specifically in lung epithelial and endothelial adaptation.
title: Immune-mediated genetic pathways resulting in pulmonary function impairment increase lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The rs9806806 SNP exhibited significant differential allele-specific activity in induced neurons, particularly showing higher activity in this cell type compared to neural progenitor cells (NPCs). This finding suggests a developmental specificity that may link it to schizophrenia risk, although it had not previously been characterized as an eQTL.
title: Cell type and condition specific functional annotation of schizophrenia associated non-coding genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs9939609 was confirmed for association with BMI in the Pelotas cohort, aligning with prior evidence linking it to obesity.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: Similar to rs9939609, rs1558902 was also associated with BMI in the Pelotas cohort, reaffirming its role in obesity-related traits.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: Located 2kb upstream of the NOD2 gene, rs76416629-G showed a negative association with BMI in the Pelotas cohort, highlighting its potential influence on weight.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The SNP rs9930333 was confirmed for its association with BMI, contributing to the understanding of genetic factors influencing obesity.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: This variant was also validated for its association with BMI, consistent with findings in previous studies of obesity-related SNPs.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The association of rs8050136 with BMI was confirmed in the Pelotas cohort, further validating its role in obesity genetics.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The SNP rs3751812 was reaffirmed for its association with BMI, aligning with earlier studies on genetic influences on obesity.
title: Admixture/fine-mapping in Brazilians reveals a West African associated potential regulatory variant (rs114066381) with a strong female-specific effect on body mass- and fat mass-indexes

finding: The SNP rs12103023 was associated with alterations in NRF2 signaling and metabolic processes in cancer. This connection was relevant to the resistance mechanisms observed in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and highlighted the role of NRF2 as a key player in tumor initiation and progression.
title: Distinct Nrf2 Signaling Thresholds Mediate Lung Tumor Initiation and Progression

finding: Historically linked with lifetime smoking and abdominal adiposity, rs889398 was considered a pleiotropic variant affecting WHR<sub>adjBMI</sub>. Its role in this association highlights the genetic factors influencing both smoking and fat distribution.
title: Estimating the causal relationship between smoking and abdominal adiposity using Mendelian randomization

finding: The variant rs1050847 was implicated in the causal pathway from lifetime smoking to WC<sub>adjBMI</sub>. This suggests a genetic basis for increased abdominal fat associated with smoking habits.
title: Estimating the causal relationship between smoking and abdominal adiposity using Mendelian randomization

finding: The SNP rs12051315 was associated with clinical implications related to DNA repair defects in high-grade serous ovarian carcinomas (HGSOC). The findings indicated that variants at this locus contributed to the understanding of how DNA repair mechanisms could influence therapeutic outcomes in EOC patients.
title: Collective amoeboid dynamics drives colonization of drug-resistant ovarian cancer cells

finding: This variant produced an early termination codon truncating most of the nuclease domain in the gene PARN, previously implicated in short telomere syndrome.
title: Novel genetic determinants of telomere length from a trans-ethnic analysis of 109,122 whole genome sequences in TOPMed

finding: The TSP rs57790054 was strongly associated with several growth and body mass phenotypes, including body mass index (BMI) and alcohol intake frequency, with a p-value of less than 4E-10. It also served as an eQTL for the gene KNOP1. Additionally, a variant in high linkage disequilibrium (LD), rs72771074, was associated with alcohol use disorder in a previous GWAS.
title: Diverse functions associate with trans-species polymorphisms in humans

finding: The Neanderthal allele at rs4784812 was validated in the context of adaptive introgression. It was predicted to alter binding for six transcription factors, including NF-Y and ELK4, which are important in the response to various environmental stimuli.
title: A signature of Neanderthal introgression on molecular mechanisms of environmental responses

finding: This SNP was identified as a GTEx eQTL for SPIRE2 and is associated with higher expression levels regulated by Vitamin D. The Neanderthal allele (T allele) was linked to increased gene expression in skin tissues for both SPIRE2 and MC1R.
title: A signature of Neanderthal introgression on molecular mechanisms of environmental responses

finding: The predicted LOF variant c.1648G>A (rs563131364) in the SLC12A3 gene was strongly associated with increased risk for severe chronic kidney disease (p=0.001, LO=1.723, ICD=N184), abnormal blood chemistry (p=0.003, LO=1.189, ICD=R7989), and retinal edema (p=0.006, LO=2.377, ICD=H3581). The mutation was also found to be protective against pure hypercholesterolemia (p=0.0396, LO=-1.512, ICD=E7800). It had a CADD PHRED score of 29.3, suggesting a high likelihood of pathogenicity in the context of SLC12A3. This variant is also predicted to manifest autosomal recessive inheritance, consistent with Gitelman syndrome.
title: Genome-wide prediction of pathogenic gain- and loss-of-function variants from ensemble learning of a diverse feature set

finding: The predicted GOF variant c.7471C>T (rs201746476) in the PIEZO1 gene was associated with risks for palpitations (p=0.009, LO=2.912, ICD=R002), abdominal pain (p=0.028, LO=1.842, ICD=R109), and viral hepatitis C susceptibility (p=0.039, LO=2.438, 2.389, ICD=B182, B1920). The mutation was linked to impaired hepatic iron metabolism, which has been implicated in the mechanism of viral hepatitis C infection. The variant had a CADD PHRED score of 25.4.
title: Genome-wide prediction of pathogenic gain- and loss-of-function variants from ensemble learning of a diverse feature set

finding: SNP rs8061552 showed significant allelic differences in expression in both K562 and SH-SY5Y cell lines and served as an eQTL for genes in the DLPFC, indicating its regulatory potential.
title: A screen of 1,049 schizophrenia and 30 Alzheimer’s-associated variants for regulatory potential

finding: The SNP rs72772740, located in the GPR139 gene, showed a significant association with changes in lateral ventricle volume. It was identified as a lead SNP with a strong influence on the rate of brain change across different phases of analysis, highlighting its relevance in brain morphology and potential implications for neurological conditions.
title: Age-dependent genetic variants associated with longitudinal changes in brain structure across the lifespan

finding: The SNP rs72772746, also located within the GPR139 gene, was associated with the rate of change in lateral ventricle volume. It demonstrated an age-independent effect, indicating its consistent influence on brain morphology throughout different life stages.
title: Age-dependent genetic variants associated with longitudinal changes in brain structure across the lifespan

finding: The rs193778 variant was part of the 99% credible set at the 16q13.13 locus and showed a significant association with T1D. This SNP mapped to a conserved cytokine-responsive regulatory element and demonstrated higher enhancer activity in cytokine-exposed β-cells when carrying the T1D-associated G allele as opposed to the A allele. This suggests that rs193778 may influence the expression of several up-regulated genes, including DEXI, which is considered a candidate gene for T1D.
title: The impact of pro-inflammatory cytokines on the β-cell regulatory landscape provides new insights into the genetics of type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs12102988 was found to be significantly associated with the glycoprofiling of the free form of prostate-specific antigen (fPSA), which was evaluated for its clinical potential as a biomarker for prostate cancer (PCa). The GIA test that utilized the glycoprofiling of fPSA demonstrated an AUC of 0.84 for early diagnosis of PCa and an AUC of 0.85 for therapy monitoring in samples analyzed from men undergoing prostate biopsy. This highlighted the clinical relevance of fPSA glycopeptides in distinguishing between prostate cancer and benign conditions.
title: Glycoprofiling of proteins as prostate cancer biomarkers: a multinational population study

finding: The SNP rs12445022 was linked to a peak associated with JPH3, where it was found that this G/A substitution significantly reduced the activity of a luciferase reporter gene, indicating its regulatory role. The linked peak was shown to correlate with JPH3 expression and was relevant to neuronal excitability and potentially linked to Huntington's disease-like phenotypes.
title: Single nucleus multiomics identifies ZEB1 and MAFB as candidate regulators of Alzheimer’s disease-specific cis regulatory elements

finding: The analysis of the rs1421085 T>C variant within the FTO gene indicated its role as a functional variant significantly enhancing thermogenesis. In knock-in mouse models, particularly those carrying the C-allele, an increase in thermogenic capacity and resistance to high-fat diet-induced adiposity was observed. Additionally, a correlation was established between the C-allele and lower birth weight, and its frequency showed an increase in colder environments, suggesting a possible selection during early human migration from warmer to colder climates.
title: The rs1421085 variant within FTO promotes but not inhibits thermogenesis and is potentially associated with human migration

finding: An association was found between the SLC7A5 SNP (rs28582913) and plasma levels of 7-Cl-KYNA. It demonstrated a recessive effect, where individuals with two copies of the 'C' allele exhibited approximately 46% lower concentrations of 7-Cl-KYNA. The findings suggested that genetic expression of SLC7A5 could regulate the availability of this active metabolite in plasma, providing insights into drug response variations.
title: Role of transporters and enzymes in metabolism and distribution of 4 chlorokynurenine and metabolites

finding: The variant rs11559000 in the MAZ gene was associated with clinically important erythroid traits, impacting 32% of the 25 erythroid-related traits analyzed from the GeneATLAS database. A significant p-value range of 10−2 to 10−5 was reported, highlighting the relevance of this SNP in the erythroid differentiation program.
title: Identification of MAZ as a novel transcription factor regulating erythropoiesis

finding: Variant rs572982482 in the MAZ promoter region was found to be associated with clinically important erythroid traits as identified in the GeneATLAS. This association contributed to 32% of the erythroid-related traits, indicating the SNP's pivotal role in erythroid differentiation with a significant p-value range of 10−2 to 10−5.
title: Identification of MAZ as a novel transcription factor regulating erythropoiesis

finding: The SNP rs72798129 located in the MAZ gene was associated with erythroid traits of clinical importance, along with two other variants. This was part of the 32% association found in 25 erythroid-related traits from GeneATLAS, reinforcing its significance in the erythroid differentiation process with a reported p-value between 10−2 and 10−5.
title: Identification of MAZ as a novel transcription factor regulating erythropoiesis

finding: At the <italic>CDH1/3</italic> locus, rs4420522 was identified as a common likely causal variant related to eQTL, meQTL, and sQTL associated with melanoma risk, affecting both <italic>CDH1</italic> and <italic>CDH3</italic> genes.
title: Cell-type-specific meQTL extends melanoma GWAS annotation beyond eQTL and informs melanocyte gene regulatory mechanisms

finding: Linkage analysis revealed a homozygous region of 5.9 Mb on chromosome 16 from genomic position 16:113,599 (rs11248850) to 16:6,035,402 (rs2059271). A maximum LOD score of 2.6577 was obtained at the ANKS3 locus, indicating a strong association in patients with nephronophthisis (NPH) related to renal ciliopathies.
title: The ANKS3/BICC1 protein complex is a master post-transcriptional regulator of NPHP1 ciliopathy-gene transcripts

finding: Linkage analysis indicated a homozygous region extending to genomic position 16:6,035,402 (rs2059271) from 16:113,599 (rs11248850). This supported the finding in the ANKS3 locus with a maximum LOD score of 2.6577, suggesting its involvement in nephronophthisis (NPH) associated renal ciliopathies.
title: The ANKS3/BICC1 protein complex is a master post-transcriptional regulator of NPHP1 ciliopathy-gene transcripts

finding: The sequence ars2-3363 corresponding to SNP rs2010 was part of the plasmid used in the analysis, highlighting its relevance in ARS activity, especially after promoter deletion studies indicated its genetic function.
title: Characterization of DNA replicators of a 75-kb region of Chromosome 2 of fission yeast, Schizosacharomyces pombe

finding: The SNP rs6498140 was found to be associated with Alzheimer's disease, particularly highlighting its role as a candidate SNP affecting enhancer activity. In the context of an enhancer proximal to the CLEC16A gene, the alternate allele exhibited the highest regulatory activity in both brain tissue and HMC3 cell samples. This alternation introduced a MEF2 transcription factor binding site motif within the enhancer, indicating that MEF2 is an active transcription factor in brain and microglia. Furthermore, there were noticeable marginal eQTL associations, especially in the frontal cortex where the alternate allele correlated with higher CLEC16A expression.
title: An in vivo massively parallel platform for deciphering tissue-specific regulatory function

finding: This SNP was linked to Graves' disease (GRD) and was part of the shared genetic architecture informing multiple autoimmune diseases.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: Associated with psoriasis (PSO), this SNP contributed to the understanding of the shared immune response pathways in AiDs.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The SNP was linked to psoriasis (PSO) and was indicated to be part of the interconnected genetic risk factors across several autoimmune diseases.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: Similar to rs10782001, this SNP was associated with psoriasis (PSO), highlighting its role in the adaptive immune response involving multiple AiDs.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: This SNP was linked to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and contributed to the observation of shared genetic risks among autoimmune diseases.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: This SNP was linked solely to primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) but indicated interactions with proteins associated with multiple AiDs, emphasizing the intricate relationship between different autoimmune conditions.
title: Unravelling the shared genetic mechanisms underlying 18 autoimmune diseases using a systems approach

finding: The SNP rs1805007 in the MC1R gene was associated with hair colour, reaching extraordinarily high significance (P < 1 x 10^-5000) for red hair. This finding replicated known non-additive effects.
title: Analysis of genetic dominance in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs8060054 was associated with the control of Wnt receptor turnover through the R-spondin-ZNRF3/RNF43 signaling module. This finding was significant because dysregulation of this pathway was implicated in cancer, illustrating the critical role of RNF43 in the context of Wnt signaling, particularly in the maintenance of intestinal stem cell homeostasis and Paneth cell differentiation.
title: Intestinal Paneth cell differentiation relies on asymmetric regulation of Wnt signaling by Daam1/2

finding: The SNP rs12051173 was linked to the modulation of breast cancer cell migration through the secretion of metalloproteinases (MMPs) by breast fibroblasts and extracellular matrix (ECM) components. This finding, as presented in the work by Lugo-Cintrón et al. (2020), illustrated the role of this SNP in enhancing our understanding of the migratory capabilities of cancer cells, particularly in a 3D microfluidic context.
title: EMT-dependent cell-matrix interactions are linked to unjamming transitions in cancer spheroid invasion

finding: The variant rs59261767, a stop-gain in ACSM2A, was linked to increased plasma levels of indolepropionic acid and complete loss of catalytic activity of the enzyme. The major allele frequency (MAF) in gnomAD was 0.012, while it was higher at 0.045 in the IGSR dataset, attributed to a greater representation of East Asian individuals in IGSR. This variant was known to be more frequent within the Japanese population.
title: Allele Dispersion Score: Quantifying the range of allele frequencies across populations, based on UMAP
